​The Oregon State Public Health Laboratory (OSPHL), many local public health departments, commercial laboratories, such as LabCorp and Quest Diagnostics, and several local health systems and providers can currently test for COVID-19. More labs and facilities may begin testing over time.
​
​

question: What are Oregon’s testing priorities for COVID-19?
answer:
Testing
availability has increased due to several factors:
Fewer
individuals are presenting with COVID-19 symptoms due to the Governor’s
stay-at-home order; 
More
hospitals and commercial laboratories are performing COVID-19 testing; 
The
Oregon State Public Health Laboratory (OSPHL) is adding groups of people it can
test for COVID-19; 
There
are more types of testing available for COVID-19.
Oregon’s testing priorities are as follows:
Test
every Oregonian who is symptomatic even if the symptom is mild. 
Test
asymptomatic individuals in group living situations where COVID-19 is suspected
such as nursing homes, adult foster homes, group homes, farmworker housing,
fishing boats, prisons, and more. 
Conduct
widespread, voluntary sample testing, particularly for at-risk populations. 
Active
and timely contact tracing.
Centralize operations and coordination of testing.


More
information is available on the OHA
COVID-19 webpage and in Oregon's Strategic Testing Plan.

question: I don't have health insurance. How can I get tested?
answer:
If you do not have health insurance, you should apply for OHP coverage, which fully covers the cost of getting tested for COVID-19 if they need it. Sign up here: https://www.oregon.gov/oha/HSD/OHP/Pages/Apply.aspx.
If you don’t want to sign up for OHP, we encourage you to see a clinician through your county health clinic or through a federally qualified health center (FQHC). You can find a list of FQHCs in Oregon here: https://www.oregon.gov/oha/HPA/HP-PCO/Documents/FQHCs.pdf.​

question: Can children wear masks?
answer:
​Parents, families and caregivers may be wondering about what age a child should be to safely wear a mask. 
Cloth face coverings should not be placed on children under age 2. 
It is very important that you never put a mask or face covering on an infant (or an adult) who is not able to adjust or remove the mask themselves. This could compromise their ability to breathe.
​

question: Is it safe to have sex during the COVID-19 outbreak?
answer:
​Yes, but with precautions. Here
are some tips on practicing safe sex during this time.
Sex in the time of COVID-19​
Spanish: Sexo en los tiempos del COVID-19

question: Can homemade masks help prevent the spread of COVID-19?
answer:
Homemade masks are not considered PPE, since their capability to protect against COVID-19 is unknown.
Homemade masks are not known to be effective in protecting the wearer against infection. Therefore, OHA does NOT recommend that healthcare personnel wear these masks when taking care of sick patients.
Never put a mask or face covering on an infant or an adult that is not able to adjust or remove the mask themselves. This could compromise their ability to breath.
The use of cloth face coverings may reduce the spread of virus and help prevent those who have the virus but do not have symptoms from passing it to others. Still, the most effective means of preventing the spread of COVID-19 is staying home and avoiding all
non-essential contact with others.
If you are sick:
You should wear a facemask when you are around other people and before you enter a healthcare provider’s office.
It can be difficult to locate a facemask; if you are unable to locate one, you can make your own using these instructions​. There are instructions for making masks with or without sewing.
​

question: Should I wear a mask to protect myself?
answer:
​For healthy people, there isn’t much evidence that wearing a mask around town is effective or necessary. Staying home and avoiding all non-essential contact with others continues to be the most important thing all of us can do to stay healthy and keep
others healthy.
Medical masks should be reserved for health care providers who are on the front lines working with patients who are most likely to have COVID-19.
People who are ill with fever and a cough might have a cold, the flu or any number of other diseases, or they may have COVID-19. They should wear a surgical mask to prevent the spread of COVID-19 germs to others. 
Never put a mask or face covering on an infant or an adult that is not able to adjust or remove the mask themselves. This could compromise their ability to breath.
For more information: Oregon Guidance on Use of Homemade Masks or Face Coveringsby the Public to Prevent Spread of COVID-19​

question: I have a chronic disease that puts me at higher risk for serious COVID-19. How can I protect myself?
answer:
​Anyone can get sick from COVID-19, but people who are older than
65 and people of any age who have a serious chronic disease are the most likely
to become very ill or die.
If you have a chronic disease like diabetes, asthma, cancer, or
heart disease, there are steps you can take to protect yourself. The fact​sheet​ below may be helpful for information about managing your chronic disease to prevent
COVID-19.

​Chronic Disease and COVID-19: What You Need to Know

Your regular health care provider can also help you discuss your
risks and ways to protect yourself.

question: Do I need to buy bottled water or store drinking water?
answer:
OHA recommends that people continue to use and drink tap water as usual. At this time, there are no indications that COVID-19 is in the drinking water supply or will affect the reliable supply of water.
While it is routinely recommended that households store a 14 day supply of drinking water as a matter of general emergency preparedness, people are encouraged to refrain from hoarding bottled water during the COVID-19 emergency since these supplies may be needed for localized drinking water issues like breaks in water mains.
​

question: Is tap water safe to drink?
answer:
The COVID-19 virus has not been detected in drinking water. The water is safe to drink as long as the water supplier is meeting all current standards.
State and federal drinking water regulations require treatment at public water systems to remove or kill pathogens, including viruses, where the source water is susceptible to microbial contaminants.

question: Should my pet wear a face mask when in public?
answer:
​Pet nose and
mouth masks may not prevent diseases that transfer by droplets spread through
coughing and sneezing. Vaccinate your pet for the most common
vaccine-preventable diseases:
Bordetella, 
Parainfluenza,
and
Canine
influenza.



These will
help protect your pet from respiratory diseases. Also, always keep your pets
fully immunized.​

question: Can I get COVID-19 from touching food or packaging exposed to COVID-19?
answer:
​The risk of transfer of viruses from food or packaging is very low, based on current research. To further minimize risk, wash hands or use hand sanitizer after handling food packaging.

​

question: Have there been changes related to Oregon Health Plan members or people who need coverage?
answer:
If you have the Oregon Health Plan and need to be tested
for novel coronavirus (COVID-19), it’s covered. If you are hospitalized because
of COVID it’s covered.
The 3/31 Oregon Medicaid waiver includes the following:
OHP
members will not lose or have a reduction in benefits during the COVID-19
crisis. There are a few exceptions to this rule and those are: 
Moving
out of state for a reason not related to COVID-19 
Request by member to close benefits 
Incarceration 
Deceased 
Aged out
Current OHP members will not lose coverage during this
crisis. This includes Cover all Kids coverage that is a state-funded only
benefit, unless they turned 19 years old and aged out of the program and will
be enrolled in CAWEM. 
You can apply for OHP without having to verify income
(submit a pay stub) with your application. You can self-attest, which will help
you get access to OHP coverage more quickly. 
Sign up at ONE.Oregon.gov​ – you may be eligible for OHP even if you have been denied in the past. 
Federal stimulus payments and increased unemployment
payments will not affect OHP eligibility. They will not be counted during the
application process or when members report a change in their household income. 
If you don’t want to apply for OHP, we encourage you
to see a clinician through your county health clinic or through a federally qualified health clinic (FQHC).

question: What is the best way to protect yourself if you have to drive a vehicle with passengers?
answer: ​Remind passengers of the need to "cover their cough." If you need to transport someone with a cough illness, ask that they wear a mask. Wipe down surfaces afterwards with an approved disinfectant.​

question: Should I use home remedies to address the outbreak?
answer:
​Regular soap and water, used properly, are extremely effective and may be the best tool we have to control COVID-19.​
DO:

Clean hands often.
Stay at least 6 feet from others.
Stay home except for essential trips (groceries, pharmacy).
Cough or sneeze into a tissue or elbow; toss tissue right away.
DON'T: 

Don't try remedies suggested on social media. Many are harmful. Scientists are testing potential medications, but nothing is approved yet for COVID-19.
Don't self-medicate by ingesting hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine (unless you have a prescription), bleach, hydrogen peroxide, excess colloidal silver, excess vitamin D, anything purporting to be a COVID-19 medication (there isn’t one). Source: Oregon Poison Center.

​

question: Staff who work with the public worry about COVID-19 and the common flu virus. They would like to wear masks. Should they?
answer:
There is no solid evidence that use of masks in the public setting reduces risk of exposure or infection to respiratory diseases like COVID-19.
It is unclear if there is any benefit for non-clinicians to wear masks to avoid exposure to respiratory illness.
In the healthcare setting, when masks are worn correctly and consistently by clinicians engaged in direct patient care, masks appear to be effective in reducing risk.
The following strategies can make a difference in decreasing spread of illness. They are recommended because they work:
Wash hands.
Cover coughs and sneezes.
Stay home when sick.
Get
the seasonal flu vaccine.

question: I feel well. However, I recently visited an affected area or had contact with a person sick with COVID-19. What’s next?
answer:
Protect your family and your
community by doing self-quarantine for the 14 days after your most recent
exposure. Please follow the plan described above under, "What is quarantine."

question: How can I keep myself from getting sick with COVID-19?
answer:
​There are
simple steps you can take to protect yourself and your family from COVID-19 as
well as influenza and other illnesses:

Wash
your hands often with regular soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water
are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer. 
Avoid
touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid
close contact with sick people or animals. 
Stay
home when you are sick. 
Cover
your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw it away. If you don’t have a
tissue, cough into your elbow.
Clean
and disinfect objects and surfaces that you frequently touch. 
Avoid
non-essential travel to regions listed
in CDC travel advisories​.







It is also important to keep your body resilient:
Eat a healthy diet.
Exercise.
Get plenty of rest.
Stay up-to-date on routine vaccines. This includes the flu
vaccine. It is not too late to get a flu shot to protect yourself from the flu,
which continues to cause illness in Oregon.
Quit smoking and
     vaping. Initial research shows that people who smoke may be more likely to
     develop serious complications from COVID-19. If you’d like to quit, free
     help is available at 1-800-QUIT-NOW or www.quitnow.net/oregon.​ 
Prevention information is available in multiple languages.
English
Español / Spanish
اللغة العربية / Arabic​
简体中文 / Simplified Chinese
繁體中文 / Traditio​nal Chinese
Foosun Chuuk / Chuukese
Lus Hmoob / Hmong
한국어 / Korean
Kajin Majol / Marshallese
Русский / Russian
Af Soomaali / Somali
Tiếng Việt / Vietnamese​

question: Can I get a test if I if I’m an essential worker or if I’m in another high-risk group?
answer:
​Oregon Health Authority (OHA) has revised guidelines for COVID-19 testing​ to prioritize populations who are disproportionately impacted by COVID-19 and all frontline workers. The guidelines continue to allow healthcare providers to make clinical decisions about their patients. In addition, if supplies allow, asymptomatic people within the congregate care or group living systems can be considered for testing.
The guidelines urge clinicians to potentially increase testing for Oregonians who may be at particular risk for contracting COVID-19. These groups include:
Those living or working in congregate care or group living
facilities; 
Communities that have been most impacted by health disparities and
health inequities, including BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
communities; 
Essential frontline workers, including
those providing healthcare services and those serving the public, such as
grocery store workers.
​

question: Are nebulizers and inhalers safe to use?
answer:
​Review of the available evidence to date suggests that use of inhaled steroids does not increase your risk of complications from COVID-19.
Stopping inhaled steroids can double your chances of having an
asthma attack in the next 6 months.
​

question: If I get sick from COVID-19, can my pet catch it from me?
answer:
At
this time, there is no evidence that animals play a significant role in
spreading the virus that causes COVID-19. Based on the limited information
available to date, the risk of animals spreading COVID-19 to people is
considered low.
CDC
is aware of a small number of pets, including dogs and
cats, reported to be infected with the virus that causes COVID-19,
mostly after close contact with people with COVID-19. Only a few of the animals
reported to be positive showed signs of illness.
If you are sick with COVID-19
(either suspected or confirmed by a test), you should restrict contact with
your pets and other animals, just like you would with people. Until we know
more about this virus, people sick with COVID-19 should avoid contact with
pets and other animals.

When possible, have another member of your household care for
     your pets while you are sick.
Avoid contact with your pet including, petting, snuggling,
     being kissed or licked, and sharing food or bedding.
If you must care for your pet or be around animals while you
     are sick, wear a cloth face covering and wash your hands before and after
     you interact with them.



If you are sick with COVID-19 and
your pet becomes sick, do not take your pet to the veterinary clinic
yourself. Call your veterinarian and let them know you have been sick with
COVID-19.

question: Where do people living with a substance use disorder go for information on treatment and recovery services?
answer:
The Vermont Department of Health has launched VTHelplink, a new, single source clearinghouse for Vermonters to receive free, confidential and personalized information and referrals to substance use prevention, treatment and recovery services throughout the state.
VTHelplink features a call center of trained staff and clinicians. Callers can get information, referrals, resources and educational materials on substance use for themselves, family and friends, or on behalf of clients.
The VTHelplink website has information resources and an online screening tool to help Vermonters learn about treatment options that meet their needs. People can also securely chat online with call center staff through the website.
The system also includes an appointment board designed to increase accessibility of treatment appointments by tracking availability by level of service (for example, residential treatment) and population (for example, people who are pregnant).
Hereâs how you can reach VTHelplink:
Dial 802-565-LINK (5465). The call center is open 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. weekdays, and 8:00 a.m to 6:00 p.m. weekends and holidays, 365 days per year.
Visit vthelplink.org.

question: Are pets from a shelter safe to adopt?
answer: There is no reason to think that any animals, including shelter pets, play a significant role in spreading the COVID-19 virus.

question: What should health care workers do?
answer:
The Health Department now has a dedicated webpage for health care workers - healthvermont.gov/covid19-providers. It includes current guidance, health alerts, and resources for protecting patients and health care workers in different settings.
Report all suspected cases of COVID-19 immediately to the Vermont Department of Health Infectious Disease Epidemiology by calling 802-863-7240 (24/7).
If you suspect that a patient with a fever or respiratory illness has COVID-19:


Give the patient a surgical mask.


Notify facility infection control personnel immediately.


Use standard precautions, contact precautions, airborne precautions, and use eye protection when entering the room.


Evaluate the patient in a private room with the door closed, ideally in an airborne infection isolation room

question: What information is available for managers and owners of apartment complexes to help prevent the spread of COVID-19?
answer: For guidance on preventing the spread of COVID-19 for managers and owners of apartment complexes, visit healthvermont.gov/COVID19-groupliving. Find information for making a plan, preparing common spaces and communicating with residents or staff, in addition to outlining the role of the Health Department.

question: I donât feel safe at work. How can I share a safety complaint about my workplace related to COVID-19?
answer: Employees with COVID-19 related concerns in the workplace can contact the Vermont Occupational Safety and Health Administration (VOSHA). Employees can submit a confidential online safety complaint form, or call toll free at 1-800-287-2765.

question: Can I get unemployment? How do I file an unemployment claim?
answer:
Find out about unemployment related to COVID-19 from the Department of Labor.
Find answers to frequently asked questions about unemployment insurance from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

question: What should families do if they are not able to get formula, diapers, or other baby necessities?
answer:
Families can call Help Me Grow-VT at 2-1-1 ext. 6 to be directed to services in their area that may be able to assist with formula, diapers, or other necessities.
Vermont WIC provides healthy foods, nutrition education, and breastfeeding support to pregnant and postpartum Vermonters and caregivers of infants and children under 5. Vermont WIC is open and invites new and returning families to join. If your family financial circumstances have changed due to a job loss or reduced hours, you could be eligible for WIC.
WIC has made a few changes to keep families and staff safe during the COVID-19 pandemic. All appointments are being done by phone and breastfeeding classes are offered online.
Apply for WIC online or text VTWIC to 855-11. You can also connect with WIC in your area.
Food banks and food shelves may be resources for families not eligible for WIC. Find more information on food access from Hunger Free Vermont.
Find more resources for families with children.

question: Should I avoid contact with pets or other animals if I am sick with COVID-19?
answer:
If you are sick with COVID-19 (either suspected or confirmed by a test), avoid contact with your pets and other animals, just like you would around other people.


When possible, have another member of your household care for your pets while you are sick.


Avoid contact with your pet, including petting, snuggling, being kissed or licked, and sharing food or bedding.


If you must care for your pet or be around animals while you are sick, wear a cloth face mask or covering and wash your hands before and after you interact with them.


Learn more about what to do if you have animals from the CDC.
Find more information on preparing for your pet from the CDC.
Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

question: Why is race and ethnicity now included in reported data on COVID-19 cases?
answer:
The Health Department is now including data about race and ethnicity on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. We recognized the need to include this information to help us understand how Vermonters were being affected by COVID-19, but in our earlier efforts to respond to the pandemic, race and ethnicity data was not always collected for each patient. A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont.
Health equity exists when all people have a fair and just opportunity to be healthy â especially those who have experienced socioeconomic disadvantage, historical injustice, and other systemic inequalities. Therefore, our epidemiology team collaborated with Vermont Information Technology Leaders (VITL) to cross-reference medical records to gain more robust race information about COVID-19 cases in Vermont.
We can use this data to help to prevent the spread of illness, improve care for patients, and present a more complete picture of how COVID-19 may be affecting everyone in Vermont.

question: How can I help care for someone sick at home?
answer: The CDC has advice on how to protect yourself or others if you are caring for someone with COVID-19. You can learn what to do when someone has symptoms of COVID-19, when someone has been diagnosed with COVID-19, or when someone who has tested positive but is not showing symptoms. Read Caring for Someone Sick at Home.

question: How can I report a person or business who is violating the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order?
answer:
The Department of Public Safety and the Vermont State Police recommended to Vermont municipal leaders and law-enforcement executives that enforcement of the Governorâs Stay Home, Stay Safe Order be handled mainly through education and voluntary compliance.


For concerns about businesses or lodging facilities that are violating the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order, use the Department of Public Safetyâs non-compliance complaint form to gather more information.


For concerns or complaints about restaurants, use the Health Departmentâs online sanitation complaint form, email FoodLodging@vermont.gov, or call 802-863-7221.


For employees to report alleged safety or health hazards, use the Vermont Occupational Safety and Health Administrationâs (VOSHA) confidential safety complaint form.


For complaints regarding individuals who are failing to self-quarantine, as required, please call your local law-enforcement agency.


Read the Attorney Generalâs Enforcement Directive.
Find out more about what the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order means to Vermonters.
Find sector-specific guidance from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development for details on which businesses are open.

question: Can ticks or mosquitoes spread the COVID-19 virus?
answer:
At this time, the CDC has no data to suggest that the COVID-19 virus or other similar coronaviruses are spread by mosquitoes or ticks. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.
Learn how to prevent mosquito bites and how to prevent tick bites.

question: I have recovered from COVID-19. Can I donate my blood plasma to help other people suffering from COVID-19?
answer:
People who have fully recovered from COVID-19 have antibodies in their blood plasma. This is the bodyâs immune response to the virus. Currently, plasma donations are only being done experimentally. It has not yet been confirmed by the scientific community. However, it could prove to be important in the future to treating serious cases of illness from COVID-19.
The Red Cross is looking for people who are fully recovered from COVID-19 and may be able to donate plasma. If you are fully recovered from a COVID-19 diagnosis that was confirmed by a lab test and would like to donate your plasma, fill out the form on the Red Cross website.

question: How can community helpers and volunteers keep from getting sick with COVID-19?
answer:
Making sure neighbors have what they need is crucial, but we need to make sure helpers and volunteers are still taking precautions to protect our most vulnerable Vermonters. Common sense practices can go a long way while Vermonters take care of each other.
The Vermont Department of Health recommends any volunteers bringing items to those who need to stay home:


Keep a distance of 6 feet away.


Avoid entering the personâs home.


Wear a cloth face mask or covering.


Wash your hands regularly.


Avoid touching your face and cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.


Stop doing community support work immediately if you feel sick or find out you have had contact with someone who is sick.


Keep a list of anyone you come into close contact with in case contact tracing is required.


Wear clean gloves when handling items that may be given to people with a weaker immune system, and when you are close to someone who may be sick.

question: How can I prepare at home?
answer:
Plan ways to care for those in your home who might be at greater risk for serious complications, like older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have underlying medical conditions. Make sure those who need regular medicine, medical supplies and equipment have what they need.


Choose a room in your home that can be used to separate sick household members from those who are healthy. Identify a separate bathroom for the sick person to use, if possible. Plan to clean these rooms, as needed, when someone is sick.


Make sure you have enough groceries and other supplies for 14 days in case you get sick and need to quarantine. Stock up on only what you will need for 14 days. Do not buy more than you will need so you can leave supplies for other people.


Get support from others. Talk with your neighbors about emergency planning. If your neighborhood has Front Porch Forum, consider joining to connect with neighbors, information and resources. Stay in touch by phone or email with family and friends, especially those who are 65 years and older, who have underlying medical conditions, or who live alone.


Take care of the emotional health of your household members. Outbreaks can be stressful for adults and children. Talk with your children about the outbreak, try to stay calm, and reassure them that they are safe.


Keep a daily list of other people you are in close contact with. As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.


Read Preventing COVID-19: Tips for Large Households or Extended Families Living in the Same Space.

question: My health care provider is out-of-state. Can I be tested in Vermont?
answer: Yes, out-of-state health care providers can refer their patients for COVID-19 testing in Vermont. Ask your health care provider for a referral.

question: Where can I find additional resources?
answer:
Visit CDCâs FAQs


Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCD) COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center


Call the VT Department of Health call center at (802) 863-7240 to talk to a person


Call 2-1-1 (if callers are having trouble calling from a cell phone, turn off WiFi then call again)


If your question still isnât answered, email AHS.VDHPublicCommunication@vermont.gov

question: How can I take care of myself, my family, or friends with the stress from COVID-19?
answer:
Feeling anxious, confused, overwhelmed or powerless is common during an infectious disease outbreak. Taking care of yourself, your friends, and your family can help you cope with stress. Helping others cope with their stress can also make your community stronger.


Take breaks from watching, reading, or listening to news stories, including social media. Hearing about the pandemic repeatedly can be upsetting.


Take care of your body. Take deep breaths, stretch, or meditate. Try to eat healthy, well-balanced meals, exercise regularly, get plenty of sleep, and avoid alcohol and drugs.


Make time to unwind. Try to do some other activities you enjoy.


Connect with others. Talk with people you trust about your concerns and how you are feeling.


Find more information on coping with COVID-19 stress, including resources for local help, self-care, suicide prevention, and domestic violence.
Find more tips for coping with stress from the CDC, including how to help children cope with stress.
Need support right now?


Call your local mental health crisis line


Text VT to 741741


Call 2-1-1 or 1-866-652-4636


Contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline or call 1-800-273-8255


For multilingual support, call 800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746

question: Can I take ibuprofen for COVID-19 symptoms?
answer:
Some early news reports suggested that non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, could worsen coronavirus disease. However, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has said it is not aware of any scientific evidence connecting the use of NSAIDs with worsening COVID-19 symptoms at this time. The FDA is investigating this issue further.
There are multiple medicines you can buy with or without a doctorâs prescription that are approved for pain relief and fever reduction. Please read warning labels on all medications before using them and consult with your health care provider about what is best for you.

question: What should I do if I need to see a dentist?
answer:
Dentists can now perform all dental procedures again, including those that generate aerosol. The dental community is confident it has the necessary knowledge, skills, office processes and equipment, testing protocols, and personal protective equipment (PPE) to safely provide care.
Contact your dentist to find out if you can be seen. If you donât have a regular dentist and need help finding one, call 211.
Do not delay care if you have:

Heavy bleeding that wonât stop
Painful swelling in or around your mouth
Pain in a tooth, teeth or jawbone
Gum infection with pain or swelling
Treatment after surgery (dressing change, stitch removal)
Broken or knocked out tooth
Denture adjustment for people receiving radiation or other treatment for cancer
Wire of braces poking your cheek or gums
Biopsy of abnormal tissue

question: Can pets get sick from COVID-19?
answer:
We are still learning about the virus that causes COVID-19, but it appears that it can spread from people to animals in some situations.
There have been a few confirmed cases of animals infected with COVID-19:

a tiger at a zoo in New York
two pet cats in New York
a cat in Minnesota
aÂ dog in New York

The CDC recommends the following:
Until we learn more about how this virus affects animals, treat pets as you would other human family members to protect them from a possible infection.
Because there is a small risk that people with COVID-19 could spread the virus to animals, CDC recommends that pet owners limit their petâs interaction with people outside their household.

Keep cats indoors when possible and do not let them roam freely outside.
Walk dogs on a leash at least 6 feet away from others.
Avoid public places where large numbers of people gather.
Do not put face coverings on pets. Covering a petâs face could harm them.

Talk to your veterinarian if your pet gets sick or if you have any concerns about your petâs health.
Learn more about what to do if you have pets and answers to frequently asked questions about COVID-19 and animals from the CDC.
Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

question: Where can I buy cloth face masks or coverings?
answer:
The Department of Public Safety has a list of where to buy face coverings from businesses.
You can also reach out to your community. Check out places like Front Porch Forum to connect with other Vermonters making cloth face masks or coverings.

question: What can I wear if my health or work environment doesn't allow me to wear a cloth face mask or covering?
answer:
People who have trouble breathing can wear a light-weight bandanna or cloth covering tied to be open at the bottom or a face shield. Face shields are generally not recommended because they are more for health care settings to protect the person wearing it from droplets getting into their eyes. Face masks or coverings, like a cloth face mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in. However, if your work environment or health does not allow you to wear a cloth face mask, wearing a face shield is better than having no barrier on your nose and mouth.
Outdoor workers who are doing strenuous work that causes heavy breathing are not required to wear a cloth face mask or covering when it is hot outside. Workers should keep masks with them and wear them when they are not exerting themselves (for example talking, resting, or interacting with other co-workers or people). It is important that workers keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible, especially when they are not wearing a mask.

question: What if Iâve had contact with someone who is under monitoring?
answer: If you have been in a home or in close contact with a person who is under monitoring, you do not need to take any additional steps â as long as you are not experiencing COVID-19 symptoms.

question: Are there any translated materials about COVID-19?
answer:
There is information about COVID-19 available in several languages from NewAmericansInVermont.com.
Find more information and translated materials from the Health Department.

question: What do employers need to do to reopen their business?
answer:
All businesses must follow mandatory health and safety requirements as they reopen.
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) has the resources businesses need on their COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses, including a step-by-step reopening guide for businesses and sector-specific guidance.
Stagnant water in plumbing systems can lead to illness or cause disease. As offices, retail businesses, gyms and other buildings begin to reopen, they should follow state guidance and recommendations before using the drinking water again. Read the CDCâs Guidance for Reopening Buildings After Prolonged Shutdown or Reduced Operation for more information.

question: How can I safely run errands for essential purposes?
answer: The CDC has guidance on how to safely run essential errands to meet basic household needs, such as going grocery shopping, getting deliveries and take-out, banking, and getting gas.

question: What is serologic, or antibody, testing and will it be used in Vermont?
answer:
Serologic testing measures antibodies in the blood of a person who has been infected with COVID-19, whether they felt sick or not. In other words, it measures the bodyâs immune response to the virus, but does not detect the virus itself.
With any test, there is always a risk of incorrect test results â false positive and false negative results. We need a good and accurate test we can rely on. The Vermont Department of Health convened a working group of experts to research antibody tests. Their findings conclude that at this time, the serologic (antibody) tests that are currently available would not produce results that are accurate or reliable enough in Vermont. The working group will continue to meet regularly and will be watching closely for changes and improvements in serologic testing. Recommendations may change based on new data.
Though certain providers may offer antibody testing in Vermont, the working group cautions against using serologic testing to make decisions about individuals, for example, using this test to establish âproof of immunity.â However, this type of test could help us better understand the population-level rate of infection from COVID-19 in Vermont.

question: Where can I get food assistance?
answer: There are multiple options for those in need to get help, including meal distribution and other food resources. Get more details on how to get food help.

question: Why is it okay to end quarantine after seven days with a negative test result?
answer: Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by Day 7. This why there is the option for people to be tested at Day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine. The test must be a PCR test.

question: What is a PCR test?
answer:
A PCR test is the most common type of COVID-19 test used today. PCR stands for polymerase chain reaction. The test identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.
PCR tests are generally the most reliable tests. Samples are analyzed at a lab, which usually takes up to a few days. A PCR test is used at pop-up testing sites offered by the Health Department.
Data on COVID-19 activity reported by the Health Department includes only PCR tests.
The PCR test used by the Vermont Department of Health Laboratory has a sensitivity rate of 95%, which means the test correctly gives a positive result 95% of the time. Sensitivity rates may be different at other labs.

question: Are there any travel restrictions if I am traveling through Vermont?
answer: If you are only traveling through and not staying in Vermont (for example, driving through Vermont to another state, flying to Vermont and immediately picking up a rental car to drive to another state), there are no quarantine or other restrictions you need to follow. If you need to make stops in Vermont or are otherwise not in a vehicle while you are traveling through Vermont, please follow these general precautions to help prevent the spread of the virus: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, and wash your hands often.

question: What do I do if one of my co-workersÂ has COVID-19?
answer: Learning that a co-worker has tested positive for COVID-19 can be stressful, but there are actions you can take to stay safe. ReadÂ what to do when your co-worker has COVID-19.

question: How can I get help finding a health care provider?
answer:
Vermont 2-1-1 listsÂ community clinics and hospital-connected clinics around the state and can connect you with one if you do not have a health care provider.
Vermont 2-1-1 does not list individual primary care providers. If you need a health care provider referral, contact your health care insurer.

question: When can I stop self-isolating (home isolation)?
answer:
People with COVID-19 who have stayed home (home isolated) can stop home isolation under the following conditions:
If you had symptoms, you can leave home and be with others after these three things have happened (unless otherwise instructed by your health care provider:

you have had no fever for at least 24 hours without the use medicine that reduces fevers AND
other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND
at least 10 days have passed since your symptoms first appeared

If you did not have any symptoms, you can leave home and be with others after:

10 days have passed since the date you had your positive test (unless otherwise instructed by your health care provider).

Your health care provider will follow CDC guidelines. In all cases, follow the guidance of your health care provider and the Health Department. The decision to stop home isolation should be made in consultation with your health care provider and the Health Department.
After stopping home isolation, continue to follow the general precautions to help keep the virus from spreading:Â wear aÂ cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others you donât live with, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

question: Do I need a negative COVID-19 test result to return to work safely?
answer:
A negative test for COVID-19 should NOT be required to return to work. The Health Department does not issue letters for employees to return to work either.
The best way to know when itâs safe for someone who tested positive for COVID-19 to return to work is to follow guidance based on the presence of symptoms, or the amount of time that has passed since the person was tested. This information is found in the employer guidance, under âWhen can employees with COVID-19 return to work?â

question: Can I wear a face shield instead of a face mask or covering?
answer:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part of your household. In private settings with people you donât live with, we recommend that you wear a face mask or covering when itâs not possible to stay 6 feet apart. However, for some people, and in some cases, a face shield may be an option.
The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person, by respiratory droplets released when an infected person talks, coughs, or sneezes. Face shields are typically used in health care settings to protect the person wearing it from droplets getting into their eyes. Face masks or coverings, like a cloth face mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in and not spreading the virus.
If you have trouble breathing or if you work in a setting where it is difficult to wear a face mask or covering, wearing a face shield is better than wearing nothing over your nose and mouth. People who have trouble breathing can also wear a light-weight bandanna or cloth covering tied to be open at the bottom. In school settings, students and adults are allowed to wear face shields, and in child care settings, providers, teachers and staff are allowed to wear face shields.
Face shields should extend below the chin, to the ears on both sides, and there should be no exposed gap between the forehead and the shieldâs headpiece. Clean them regularly â especially if condensation or droplets are visible on the inside of the shield â and handle them like face masks or coverings when putting them on or removing them. (see âWhat is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?â on this page for more details).

question: Is it safe to send my children back to school or child care?
answer:
Yes, based on current data and levels of the COVID-19 virus in Vermont, it is safe â and important â for children to go to school or child care for in-person learning. On July 27, the Vermont Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics asked schools to prioritize in-person attendance for preschool to grade 5, and for students with special needs.
We know much more about the virus now than we did in March when schools closed for the spring. The Health Department can track data in real time and respond to cases quickly with our contact tracing teams. We also have robust testing and contact tracing system in Vermont that will support schools in containing the virus if there is a case.
Children need structure, relationships with their peers, teachers, and other adults for their academic, social, and emotional development. Although remote learning is an important tool during the pandemic, it can lead to even greater gaps in equity. Public health and education experts considered all these factors when writing Vermontâs guidance to reopen schools, which focuses on the safety of teachers, staff, and students.
We are seeing more cases of COVID-19 in children nationwide and in Vermont, but that is not surprising as states have reopened, and more testing has become available.
We recognize there may be cases in schools as they reopen. This is why Vermontâs reopening guidance outlines ways to keep the virus out of schools and prevent it from spreading through physical distancing, face masks or coverings, hand hygiene, and contact tracing.

question: Where is it safe to travel internationally? Is it safe to go on a cruise ship or river cruise?
answer:
If you are planning on traveling internationally, check the current list of Travel Advisories by country from the U.S. Department of State, and visit travel.state.gov for detailed information on safe international travel.
You can also find the latest health guidance on international travel from the CDC, and read the FAQs for Travelers.
The CDC recommends no one travel on cruise ships, including river cruises, worldwide, especially people with an increased risk of serious illness. Thatâs because the risk of COVID-19 on cruise ships is high. Learn more about cruise ships and river cruise voyages.

question: I need to drop off someone at college. Do I need to quarantine?
answer:
Yes. You have two options:

You follow the State of Vermontâs travel and quarantine requirements OR
You do the drop-off while under quarantine conditions.

Here are the quarantine conditions for option 2:

You must travel by personal vehicle to and from Vermont.
Do not enter any college facilities. You may help the student unload at the curb only.
Wear a face mask any time you are outside of your vehicle.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
If your drive is farther than a single day trip, you may stay at a lodging property only if you quarantine at that property for your entire stay. This means you must stay in the room or house and not leave to go to the grocery store, restaurants or any other places where you might come into contact with other people. You may not use lodging property amenities such as pools, spas, gyms, recreation equipment or other general use facilities.

We strongly encourage you contact the school before you travel to find out if there are any move-in restrictions or rules.

question: Do I need documentation to certify that I completed my quarantine or received a negative test result before I travel to Vermont?
answer:
If you are a visitor and staying at a lodging, camping or short-term rental property in Vermont, you must sign a Certificate of Compliance certifying that you have met the quarantine requirement or have traveled from an approved county with a low rate of active cases.
In general, we rely on every visitorâs and every Vermonterâs voluntary compliance of the Governorâs orders to protect the health and safety of all. Vermonters and visitors are encouraged to take responsible common-sense measures in our daily lives to make sure we all are following CDC and Vermont Department of Health guidelines to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

question: How much does the test cost?
answer: There is no cost to individuals for a PCR test for COVID-19.

question: How can I be safe from COVID-19 infection and prevent an overdose?
answer:
Substance use may increase the risk of becoming seriously ill or dying from COVID-19, but more evidence is needed. At the same time, an opioid overdose is an immediate risk to your life. Know that stimulants may also have fentanyl in them, an opioid. Below are some tips to help avoid an overdose or be better prepared if one happens and to reduce your risk of getting COVID-19.
If you are alone:

Call, text or send a Facebook or other type of message to someone you trust. Tell them youâre going to use and make a safety plan. For example, ask them to call you in a certain number of minutes. If they donât hear from you, they should follow your plan. This could include coming over to check on you, calling a family member to check on you, or calling 911.
Call Never Use Alone at 800-484-3731 or message them on Facebook. Theyâll wait while you use and call for emergency services if you donât respond after a certain period of time.
Have Naloxone with you. Put it where someone checking on you will easily see it.
Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.

If youâre not alone:

Try to keep a 6-foot distance from the other people youâre with, unless you live with them. People who live in the same household donât need to stay 6 feet apart.
Anyone in the room should wear a face mask or covering if they are not using and not part of your household.
Make sure someone you trust has naloxone on hand, and they arenât using at the moment.
Let them know when you are using so they can check in and give naloxone if needed.
Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.

Whenever and wherever you use, these tips can help prevent an overdose:

Use one drug at a time (donât mix).
Know your tolerance. Use less if you havenât used in a while, or if youâve been sick, lost weight, or if something else has lowered your tolerance.
Test for fentanyl or assume there is fentanyl in your supply.
Start low and go slow. You can use more later.
Use in a lower risk way, like snorting instead of injecting or smoking.
Consider getting on medication assisted treatment (methadone, bupe, suboxone, etc.).
Call 802-565-LINK or go to VTHelplink to find a treatment center.

About wearing face masks or coverings:
Wearing a mask reduces the risk of transmission of COVID-19. However, substance use can impact your breathing and wearing a mask can make it worse. Plus, if you canât take your own mask off (like if youâre nodding out), you shouldnât wear one. When using substances with other people, particularly opioids, you may choose to stay 6 feet apart and not wear masks.
More information:

Tips to prevent an opioid overdose (Harm Reduction Coalition)
Helping during an overdose and finding Naloxone (Health Department)
Guidance for People Who Use Substances on COVID-19 (Yale)
Safer Drug Use During the COVID-19 Outbreak (Harm Reduction Coalition)

question: How many people who have tested positive for or have symptoms of COVID-19 are in the hospitals?
answer: The number of people who are currently hospitalized with COVID-19 and the number of people who are suspected to have COVID-19 but have not yet been confirmed (reported as hospitalized under investigation) are updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. Below the map, you can find information on how the hospitalization data and data for people currently hospitalized are reported.

question: Iâm a health professional and would like to volunteer. How do I get a temporary license?
answer:
If you are a health care professional, you can quickly become temporarily licensed to provide care during the COVID-19 pandemic. You can be granted a temporary license if you:

Are licensed and in good standing in other states
Were licensed in Vermont, but your license lapsed in recent years

There are no fees of any kind to obtain a temporary emergency license.
To apply for a license or get more information about the process, contact the licensing authority for your profession:

Board of Medical Practice (medical doctors, physician assistants, and podiatrists) or 802-657-4223.
Office of Professional Regulation (other health care professions â including nurses and osteopathic physicians) or 802-828-1505.

question: Can you tell me more information about a person diagnosed with COVID-19?
answer:
In order to protect a personâs personal health information and privacy, we canât provide details about specific cases. We are focusing our efforts on contact tracing to help identify people who have been in close contact with a person who has tested positive for COVID-19. We will keep the public informed as we are able, including any known risk to the public.
Find up-to-date COVID-19 information on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

question: What types of disinfectants should I be using to clean?
answer:
Find tips from the CDC on how toÂ clean and disinfect your home routinely and when someone is sick.
Make sure you are using cleaning products and disinfectants safely. Follow these guidelines:

Wear protective gear (such as gloves and eye protection)
Use them in a well-ventilated area
Follow the directions on the label
Use no more than the amount recommended on the label
Use water at room temperature for dilution (unless the label says a different temperature)
Donât mix chemicals
Label diluted cleaning products
Store them out of reach of children and pets

You should never eat, drink, breathe or inject these products into your body or apply directly to your skin as they can cause serious harm. Do not wipe or bathe pets with these products or any other products that are not approved for animal use.
If you feel sick after using disinfectants, you can chat with the New England Poison Control Center on their website, call 1-800-222-1222 or text POISON to 85511.

question: Who do I contact if I have a concern or a complaint about a school that is not complying with the Stateâs guidance?
answer:
We recommend that you reach out to the school administration or the supervisory union administration â such as the principal, superintendent or independent school head â with your information and concerns. Find the list of superintendents.
The Health Department has worked closely with the Agency of Education to develop safety and health guidance and to support schools with implementing them so that we can continue to do as well as the State has during the pandemic.

question: Is it safe to go to the hospital?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of a more serious medical condition, such as heart attack or stroke, it is important to get medical care right away. Call 9-1-1 or go to the emergency room if your symptoms are life-threatening. Call your doctor if your symptoms are not life-threatening.
It is safe to seek care at Vermont hospitals. They have measures in place to protect patients in the hospital from getting COVID-19. This includes separating patients with COVID-19 from other patients. There is a greater risk to staying at home if you're experiencing symptoms of a serious medical condition than going to the hospital.
If you are planning to visit someone at the hospital, be sure to check the hospitalâs visitation policy first.
Health care providers may be doing some clinic visits, diagnostic imaging, and outpatient surgeries and procedures. Hospitals are also scheduling and performing inpatient surgeries and procedures if they follow the required health and safety precautions. Read the Governorâs press release for details.

question: I traveled internationally or by cruise ship. Do I or my household members need to quarantine?
answer:
If youâve returned from international travel or from a cruise ship or river cruise voyage, follow the CDCâs after travel guidance when you return to the U.S. When you return to Vermont, you must quarantine for 14 days. You have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
Other members of your household who did not travel do not need to quarantine, but should observe themselves for symptoms for 14 days.
Learn about isolation, quarantine and self-observation.
If you or your household members develop symptoms of COVID-19, contact your health care provider right away. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
Find more information from the CDC about:

returning from cruise ship and river cruise voyages
travel recommendations by country
FAQs for Travelers

question: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
answer:
It is not yet known if people who recover from COVID-19 can get infected again. Data to date show that a person who has had and recovered from COVID-19 may have low levels of virus in their bodies for up to three months after diagnosis. This means that if the person who has recovered from COVID-19 is retested within three months of initial infection, they may continue to have a positive test result, even though they are not spreading COVID-19.
There are no confirmed reports to date of a person being reinfected with COVID-19 within three months of initial infection. However, additional research is ongoing. Therefore, if a person who has recovered from COVID-19 has new symptoms of COVID-19, the person may need an evaluation for reinfection, especially if the person has had close contact with someone infected with COVID-19. The person should isolate and contact a health care provider to be evaluated for other causes of their symptoms, and possibly retested.

question: What is monitoring?
answer: Monitoring means travelers or close contacts who are enrolled in Sara Alert for daily symptom check reminders. The Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard includes the number of people being monitored and the number of people who have completed monitoring and is updated every day.

question: What details can you share about people who have died from COVID-19?
answer:
The total number of deaths across the state and for each county are updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. You can find information on how the data for deaths are reported in the notes section of the dashboard. There are also more frequently asked questions about the data above the dashboard.
Information on the number of deaths from COVID-19 in the U.S. is available from the CDC.
Weekly summaries of Vermont COVID-19 data include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

question: Is there a medicine I can take to prevent or treat COVID-19?
answer:
There are no drugs or other therapeutics currently approved to prevent or treat COVID-19. Most people who get COVID-19 can manage their symptoms at home with rest, drinking fluids and taking fever-reducing medication.
Scientists are working to develop effective treatments.
Though the anti-malarial drugs chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, among others, have been widely discussed as potential treatments, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said there are no data currently available that show how these drugs could be used to treat COVID-19. In fact, there are significant potential risks to taking such drugs, including death.
Talk to your health care provider before taking any substance alleged to prevent or treat COVID-19.
Providers should only prescribe these drugs for individuals with diagnosed conditions, and not for prevention, to help maintain the supply for Vermonters who need them.

question: What does âinfectious periodâ mean?
answer:
The infectious period is the period of time when someone with COVID-19 has a high chance of spreading the virus to others. The infectious period starts two days before any symptoms began â or for people with COVID-19 who don't have symptoms, two days before they got tested â and continues until they have recovered.
People who had close interactions with the person with COVID-19 during this time are at risk and may be considered close contacts.

question: Where can I find information on testing results for Vermont colleges and universities?
answer: The Department of Financial Regulationâs School Reopening web page includes links to each Vermont college and university that is currently maintaining a public dashboard or otherwise publicly maintaining information regarding their COVID-19 testing results.

question: When can a person return to work if they have a symptom or multiple symptoms of COVID-19?
answer:
If you are sick with any symptoms of COVID-19,
Talk with your health care provider to determine if:

your symptoms are due to COVID-19 or some other reason
you should or should not go to public places or work

If COVID-19 is suspected, your health care provider can refer you for testing. Stay home while you are waiting for your test results. If you test positive, a Health Department contact tracer will reach out to walk you through what to do next.
You will be advised to stay home from work and other activities until:

fever has resolved for at least 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing medications, and other symptoms (like cough or shortness of breath) have improved â AND â
at least 10 days have passed since symptoms first appeared.

If you are sick due to something other than COVID-19, you should stay out of work until:

you have been without fever for 24 hours without using fever-reducing medications (if you had a fever) â AND â
any other symptoms have resolved or are improving.

question: Are there resources available to help with home schooling?
answer:
TheÂ Vermont Agency of EducationÂ and Vermont PBS have extended their partnership to support in-person, hybrid and distance learning models.
Vermont teachers, families and students have continued access to free educational resources via television broadcast along with digital streaming and resources.Â It is available on all cable systems and for free over-the-air through a digital antenna without the need for a cable subscription or broadband internet access.
Find additional strategies and resources for educators and families from the Agency of Education.

question: What is an antigen test?
answer:
An antigen test for COVID-19 is a newer type of test that identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus. Antigen tests provide results much more quickly than PCR tests (the most common type of test used to diagnose and confirm COVID-19 infection).
Though antigen tests may be available in Vermont, the Health Department only recommends antigen testing in certain circumstances:

For people who have symptoms of COVID-19. So far, studies on antigen tests have only been done on people with symptoms, and we do not have evidence about the accuracy of the antigen test on people without symptoms.
Health care providers may use antigen testing when PCR testing is not available or when results are needed quickly. This may be when people who are having symptoms get tested at their doctorâs office or when patients are being admitted to hospitals that donât have a lot of PCR tests available.
Antigen tests may be used to screen people to identify those who need a more definitive test. Antigen tests are particularly helpful when used to test people in the early stages of infection (within the first 5 to 7 days of having COVID-19 symptoms) when the viral load is generally the highest. For example, long-term care facilities could screen residents and staff who are not having symptoms, but only if the tests were done at least weekly.

When used appropriately to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, antigen tests have a higher chance of missing an active infection than PCR tests. This means that if you have symptoms, you may receive a negative result but still be infected with COVID-19.
We are monitoring how these antigen tests evolve and how results can best be used. Right now, people who test positive from antigen tests are not considered to have a lab-confirmed case of COVID-19 and are not included in our total number of cases. However, we consider these cases âpresumptive positivesâ and recommend they follow the same guidelines as a positive case to stay home (self-isolate). We also conduct contact tracing and recommend a PCR test to confirm the positive result.
Antigen tests are different from antibody (serologic) tests, which identify people who have previously been infected with the coronavirus and do not show whether a person is currently infected.
Learn more:

Use of Antigen Testing in Vermont â Health Update October 1, 2020
Coronavirus testing basics from the Food & Drug Administration
Considerations for Implementation of SARS-CoV-2 Rapid Antigen Testing from the Association of Public Health Laboratories.

question: Do I need to quarantine if I'm traveling for an essential purpose (like work in a neighboring state or parental shared custody)?
answer:
If you are traveling for essential purposes, you do not need to quarantine. Essential travel includes travel for personal safety, health care, care of others, parental shared custody, for food, beverage or medicine, to attend preK-12 school or college, or for work.
If you live near a border and regularly travel to and from a neighboring state, you may make day trips to that state for work, health care, to attend preK-12 school or college, and other essential needs like groceries or visitation for parental shared custody, without quarantining.
The exemption to quarantineÂ only applies to the person under essential travel rules. It does not apply to anyone else who travels with you. For example, you travel for work and your child comes with you. Your child will need to quarantine for 14 days when you return to Vermont, but you wonât need to.
However, if you travel out of Vermont for leisure and to a location that is not in an approved county with low rates of active cases or travel by plane, train, bus or other means of public transportation, you must quarantine for 14 days in Vermont upon return. This includes day trips.
Additionally, if you come in close contact with someone who has COVID-19, you must quarantine for 14 days, no matter where the contact occurred. Learn more about what to do if youâre a close contact of someone with COVID-19.
You have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

question: I have parental shared custody. Can my child and I travel without quarantining?
answer:
Travel for parental shared custody is considered essential travel. This means that you and your child do not need to quarantine if:

You are returning to Vermont after visiting your child out of state.
Your child lives out of state and is visiting you in Vermont.
You live out of state and your child is returning to Vermont after visiting you.

You can travel by personal vehicle, plane, train, bus or other means of transportation. We encourage you to choose the form of travel with the lowest risk when you can (personal vehicle) and to follow the general precautions:

Stay home and do not travel if you are sick.
Keep a 6-foot distance from people you don't live with.
Wear a face mask or coveringÂ when you can't keep 6 feet apart.
Avoid crowded indoor spaces.
Wash your hands often.
Limit your stops when traveling and only stop when necessary (for example, for fuel, food or rest).
Try to plan your stops in an approved county with low rates of active cases.

However, if you and your child travel out of Vermont for leisure and to a location that is not in an approved county with low rates of active casesor by plane, train, bus or other means of public transportation, you and your child must quarantine for 14 days in Vermont upon return. This includes day trips.
Additionally, anyone who comes into close contact with someone who has COVID-19must quarantine for 14 days, including you or your child, no matter where the contact occurred. Learn more about what to do if youâre a close contact of someone with COVID-19.
You have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.

question: Is it safe to wear gaiters instead of masks?
answer:
Generally, we recommend face masks and coverings that are made of at least two layers. Materials with tighter weaves, like cotton T-shirt material, are better at trapping respiratory droplets and preventing the spread of the COVID-19 virus than materials with loose weaves, like gaiters.
If you choose to wear a gaiter as a face covering, fold it over so it is two layers. Based on a few experiments in adults, gaiters with one layer trap the least amount of respiratory droplets. Gaiters with two layers trap more droplets than gaiters with one layer. Gaiters folded over into two layers have a similar effectiveness at trapping respiratory droplets as two layers of cotton T-shirt material.

question: How does COVID-19 spread?
answer:
COVID-19 most commonly spreads during close contact through respiratory droplets
COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person, including between people who are near each other (within about 6 feet).
When people with COVID-19 cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe they produce respiratory droplets. Another person can become infected if they inhale the droplets, or if droplets land in their nose or mouth.
COVID-19 can sometimes spread through airborne transmission
As the respiratory droplets travel further from the person with COVID-19, the concentration of these droplets decreases. Larger droplets fall out of the air due to gravity. Smaller droplets and particles spread apart in the air.
It is possible for COVID-19 to be transmitted under certain circumstances when very small respiratory droplets remain airborne. These small particles can infect someone who is more than 6 feet away.
This airborne transmission is uncommon, but has occurred in situations such as indoors when a person with COVID-19 had symptoms and been coughing for longer than 30 minutes. Other examples include shouting, singing or exercising, or being in a building without proper ventilation that allowed a buildup of respiratory droplets or particles.
COVID-19 spreads less commonly through contact with contaminated surfaces
Respiratory droplets can also land on surfaces and objects. It is possible that a person could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or eyes, but this is not thought to be a common way that COVID-19 spreads. This can be prevented by washing your hands before you touch your face, mouth or eyes.
Not everyone infected with the virus has symptoms.
Follow these general precautions to help prevent the virus from spreading:

Keep a 6-foot distance from people you donât live with.
Wear a face mask or covering when you canât keep 6 feet apart.
Avoid crowded indoor spaces.
Wash your hands often.
Stay home if you are sick.

Learn more from the CDC about how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.

question: How long can the virus live on surfaces?
answer:
It is possible that a person could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or eyes, but this is not thought to be a common way that COVID-19 spreads. This can be prevented by washing your hands before you touch your face, mouth or eyes. The virus is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person.
If someone is sick with COVID-19, you should regularly clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces (for example, tables, countertops, doorknobs, light switches, toilets, faucet handles and sinks). Follow the steps for how to clean and disinfect your home from the CDC.

question: How does being indoors with the windows closed affect my risk of getting COVID-19?
answer:
Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading the COVID-19 virus and becoming infected with it.
The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person, by respiratory droplets when people with COVID-19 cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe.
It is possible for COVID-19 to be transmitted under certain circumstances when very small respiratory droplets remain airborne. These small particles can infect someone who is more than 6 feet away. This airborne transmission is uncommon, but can happen when inside a building without proper ventilation that has allowed a buildup of respiratory droplets or particles.
In general, the more people there are in an indoor environment, the more there is a need for ventilation with outdoor air.
There is going to be some level of risk if you are indoors with people you donât live with. The level of risk can depend on multiple things, including:

How big the space is â Larger rooms or areas that allow enough space for everyone to keep a 6-foot distance from others are less of a risk than small rooms or areas that can easily get crowded.
How many people are in the room or area â A small number of people reduces your risk compared to many people who are not able to keep a 6-foot distance from others.
How much ventilation there is â Open windows and doors for ventilation with outdoor air. If it is too cold outside to open windows, then setting up a fan to pull air out of the room can reduce your risk. However, using a fan to blow air into or around the room or using ceiling fans is not recommended since they could keep the virus in the air for longer.
How humid the room or area is - Coronaviruses thrive when the relative humidity is below 40%, which usually happens when buildings are heated during the fall and winter. If you can, run a humidifier to maintain a relative humidity of at least 40% in the room or area where people are gathering.
What the people are doing in the room or area â Places where people can continuously wear a mask (for example, a family gathering without food or drink or a library) are less of a risk than places where people might take their masks off (for example, dinner at a friendâs house or a restaurant).

Be sure to take these general precautions any time you are in an indoor environment, whether you are at home or in another building:

Stay home if you are sick.
Avoid crowded indoor spaces.
Wear a face mask or covering.
Keep a 6-foot distance from people you donât live with.
Wash your hands often.

Learn more:

How to increase ventilation in your home from the EPA
FAQs about indoor air and COVID-19 from the EPA
Hosting gatherings or cook-outs from the CDC
Attending an event or gathering from the CDC
Holiday celebrations from the CDC

question: Can I use reusable grocery bags?
answer:
Yes, it is safe to use reusable, or cloth, grocery bags. The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly throughÂ close contact from person to person, by respiratory droplets when people withÂ COVID-19 cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe.
Respiratory droplets can also land on surfaces and objects. It is possible that a person could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or eyes, but this is not thought to be a common way that COVID-19 spreads. This can be prevented by washing your hands before you touch your face, mouth or eyes.
Stores and food service establishments no longer provide plastic bags at check-out. You have the option to purchase paper bags for 10 cents each or use reusable bags. If a store has temporarily banned reusable bags, consider putting your groceries back into your cart and bag them at your car.
Make sure you clean your reusable bags regularly, which can also help prevent illnesses from bacteria, such as E.coli, that are from meat and unwashed fruits and vegetables.
Find more information and tips about the single-use plastics ban from the Department of Environmental Conservation.

question: Is there any financial assistance available?
answer:
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) has answers to questions regarding financial assistance (for example, mortgage, utility bills, internet, and taxes) and housing (for example, paying rent, short-term housing and emergency housing) on its COVID-19 Resource Recovery Center.
Housing assistance programs for those affected by COVID-19 are available. Find information on rental assistance and mortgage assistance.

question: Is it safe to go grocery shopping?
answer:
Currently, there is no evidence to show that the COVID-19 virus is spread through food or food packaging. Follow these precautions to help keep the virus from spreading and to protect yourself while you shop:

Stay home if you are sick. Ask a family member, friend or neighbor to help you get your groceries, or have food or groceries delivered.
Wear a face mask or covering while youâre in the store.
Keep a 6-foot distance from people you don't live with whenever possible. Follow any arrows on the floor or other signage that directs how people should move through the store.
Use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol after you leave the store. Wash your hands with soap and water when you return home and after you put away your groceries.

Read more about shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the Food and Drug Administration.

question: What do I need to know before I have an outpatient or inpatient procedure?
answer: If you are scheduled for an outpatient (or inpatient) procedure, you may need to be tested for COVID-19. The health care provider doing the procedure will test you no more than 7 days before the procedure. You must self-isolate until the test and the procedure. You will receive your test results from your health care provider before the procedure.

question: Can I get COVID-19 from my pets or other animals? Can animals carry the virus on their skin or fur?
answer:
According to the CDC and based on the limited information available to date, the risk of animals spreading COVID-19 to people is low. There is no evidence that the COVID-19 virus can spread to people from the skin, fur or hair of pets.
However, because animals can sometimes carry other germs that can make people sick, itâs always a good idea to practice healthy habits around pets and other animals, such as washing your hands before and after interacting with them.
Learn more about what to do if you have pets and answers to frequently asked questions about pets and animals from the CDC.
Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

question: Can sunlight disinfect surfaces?
answer: We donât know yet. According to the CDC, early scientific data suggest the COVID-19 virus can be killed by the sunâs ultraviolet (UV) light. However, the ability of the sunâs UV light to kill the virus on surfaces needs more research. Factors â such as cloudiness, latitude (distance from the equator), time of day, and amount of time exposed to the sunâs UV light â determine how effectively the virus is killed.

question: How can I tell if Iâm sick with COVID-19 or something else?
answer:
Sometimes you may be having symptoms of COVID-19 but are sick with something else. Talk to your health care provider about your symptoms and whether you should be tested for COVID-19. You can also check your symptoms on this chart of COVID-19 symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.
If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.

question: Are syringe service programs (needle exchanges) still open?
answer:
Yes! Services have been changed to limit the risk of getting COVID-19. Also, some services may not be available like walk-in HIV/Hepatitis C testing. See the list of services that are being offered at each program.
Find a syringe service program near you.
You can also call VT Helplink for free, confidential alcohol and drug support and referrals at 802-565-LINK or search for a syringe service program.

question: How can I be safer when using drugs?
answer:
