Syringe service programs have supplies and information to help keep you safe. Their services are anonymous and free. Find a syringe service program near you and give them a call.
For more information, read the Harm Reduction Coalitionâs guidance for people who use drugs and harm reduction programs.
You can also call VT Helplink for free, confidential alcohol and drug support and referrals at 802-565-LINK or search for a syringe service program.

question: Is there temporary housing available if I might have or have tested positive for COVID-19?
answer:
There is temporary housing available â commonly referred to as the motel voucher program â for people experiencing homelessness who are suspected to have or tested positive for COVID-19 and donât require hospitalization.
Call the Vermont Economic Services Division at 1-800-479-6151 Monday through Thursday from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. and Friday from 8 a.m. to 4:15 p.m. After hours, you can call 2-1-1.
If you need to isolate or quarantine due to COVID-19 and donât have a suitable home environment, there is temporary housing available. Learn more about isolation/quarantine and recovery housing sites.

question: Can the COVID-19 virus spread through pools and hot tubs?
answer:
There is no evidence that the virus can spread to people through the use of pools, hot tubs or water playgrounds. Proper operation and disinfection of the water (for example, with chlorine and bromine) should kill the virus.
When youâre at a pool or hot tub, follow these steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask any time youâre not in the water and canât keep 6 feet apart from people you donât live with.

Learn more about healthy swimming, find information for residential pool or hot tub owners, and find more frequently asked questions about pools, hot tubs and water playgrounds from the CDC.

question: Can I get COVID-19 from swimming in a lake or river?
answer:
There is no evidence that the COVID-19 virus spreads to people through the water in lakes, oceans, rivers or other natural bodies of water.
The virus has been found in untreated wastewater, which means it could possibly enter lakes or rivers when untreated wastewater is discharged into waterways after rainstorms or for other reasons. According to the CDC, it is currently thought that the risk of getting COVID-19 from properly designed and maintained sewerage systems is low. There has been no evidence that a person can get COVID-19 by swallowing or coming in contact with water contaminated by feces (poop) from an infected person.
The Health Department recommends that towns do routine weekly E. coli testing and after large rainstorms during the swim season. These tests are a good indication of the water quality, meaning that if the E. coli levels are low, then COVID-19 virus levels are also expected to be low.
The best practices for staying healthy while swimming are to obey signage at beaches, do not swim during and following large rainstorms, and do not swallow the water.
When you are at a beach or swimming spot, plan to âarrive, play, and leaveâ â avoiding gathering before and after activities and giving others space. Follow these steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask any time youâre not in the water and canât keep 6 feet apart from people you donât live with.

Learn more about healthy swimming from the CDC.

question: How can we safely carpool?
answer:
If possible, donât carpool. This is because people will be within 6 feet of each other and in an enclosed space. If you need to carpool to work, school or sports games or practices, itâs best to:

Wear masks at all times.
Limit the number of people you carpool with.
Carpool with the same people, ideally those who are following the COVID-19 prevention steps in their day-to-day lives.
Keep a log of who you and your family have carpooled with that includes dates, names of other riders, and the duration of the ride.
Keep the windows or vents open for fresh air.
Cover your coughs and sneezes.
Clean and disinfect surfaces often.
Wash or sanitize your hands before getting in and out of the car.

Do not carpool if you are sick or have been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.
Read the CDCâs tips on carpooling safely.

question: Does smoking or vaping increase the risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19?
answer:
People who smoke â tobacco, cannabis or anything else â have an increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19, a disease that attacks the lungs. Vaping damages your lungsâ immune system and is linked to a substantially increased risk of COVID-19 among teenagers and young adults.
802Quits is Vermontâs tobacco quit resource. Help is available online and by phone for Vermonters 13 and older. Call 1-800-QUIT-NOW for one-on-one coaching, available 24/7, with free nicotine replacement therapy, email and text support, or visit 802quits.org for online workshops and customized quit tools.
My Life, My Quit is a free, confidential quit program designed for teens, available by texting âStart My Quitâ to 855-891-9989 or calling to talk with a coach.
By quitting, youâll also protect people in your household by reducing their exposure to the dangerous chemicals in secondhand smoke and aerosol as you spend more time at home during the pandemic.

question: Can I travel to or from Canada?
answer:
Check CDCâsÂ travel notices for Canada and read CanadaâsÂ entry restrictions for current information about travel to or from Canada.
Follow the CDCâsÂ after travel guidanceÂ when you return to the U.S. When you return to Vermont, you must quarantine for 14 days. You have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.

question: What does social distancing mean?
answer:
Social distancing means maintaining a physical distance (at least 6 feet or 2 meters, for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period) from people you do not live with. This includes when youâre inside a store, gathering with friends or family, or outside for exercise or a walk.
The COVID-19 virus is thought to spread mainly throughÂ close contact from person to person, by respiratory droplets when people with COVID-19 cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe.Â A person can be infected and not have any symptoms. In addition to keeping a 6-foot distance from others, these are things you can do to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask when youâre outside and canât keep 6 feet apart or anytime youâre inside with people you donât live with.

Learn more aboutÂ why, how and when to do these things and more about getting together with friends and family.

question: Do I need to quarantine if out-of-state visitors are staying in my home?
answer:
If you are hosting travelers under quarantine in your home or lodging, you do not also need to quarantine. That means you can go to school, work, or the grocery store. However, you need to stay at least 6 feet from the people who are under quarantine. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with the people who are hosting them. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.
Visitors from certain counties with low rates of active cases (âgreenâ counties) do not need to quarantine.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

question: How is Vermont deciding when it is safe to reopen?
answer:
Most recent modeling data suggests Vermont has reached its peak in the number of new cases of COVID-19, hospital capacity, and the number of people who are currently infected with COVID-19.
However, it is important to remember that not everyone infected with the virus has symptoms and there are still many people who are currently infected and could spread it to others.
Vermont is looking at four key measures to inform steps to reopen:

Ongoing reduction in cases for at least 14 days
A health care system that is safely able to treat all patients without exceeding its capacity or using crisis standards of care
The ability to test all people with symptoms
Widespread active monitoring of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 and tracing their close contacts

To continue on this path, it is critical that Vermonters continue to follow these prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask when youâre outside and canât keep 6 feet apart or anytime youâre inside with people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.
Read the latest Vermont COVID-19 modeling projections from the Vermont Department of Financial Regulation.

question: What are some ways I can talk about my COVID-19 "comfort level" when making plans with friends and family?
answer:
As life picks up again, we are learning there is a lot to discuss before seeing friends and family to feel comfortable and stay safe. Here are four tips to help have the âCOVID Talkâ â a conversation to negotiate boundaries and establish expectations ahead of time.

Ask questions. Before you get together, start with an open and honest conversation about what everyone has been doing to stay healthy and how they have been socializing. Consider everyoneâs worries, boundaries and possible COVID-19 exposure risk so you can all get on the same page.
Focus on what you need. Using âIâ instead of âyouâ statements helps people avoid feeling defensive or judged. In fact, blaming and shaming may actually increase push back and the likelihood of risk-taking behaviors. We recommend sharing what youâre comfortable with based on your own perspective instead of making demands of others.
Share why it is important to you. Share what level of risk works for you and why. It might be different for others. Some people feel comfortable taking on a moderate amount of risk in their lives. Others may not feel comfortable taking on any risk. Focusing on your own reasons for staying safe can help people to better understand and get on board.
Set boundaries and stick to them. We are all for keeping it friendly, open and non-judgmental â but that doesnât mean you have to skimp on your safety! Itâs OK to be clear and straightforward with what you need to feel safe and comfortable. Itâs also okay to decline invitations or leave situations that feel too risky. You should never have to feel bad or apologize for prioritizing your safety. Lead by example by sticking to what works for you and avoiding judgment.

Find some examples of the âCOVID Talkâ.

question: Are children more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus? How can I help my children from getting sick?
answer:
No. Based on available evidence, children do not appear to be at higher risk for COVID-19 than adults. While some children and infants have been sick with COVID-19, adults make up most of the known cases to date. However, a few children have developed multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-C). Currently, information about MIS-C is limited, and the CDC is working to learn more.
You can teach your children to do the same things everyone can do to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask when youâre outside and canât keep 6 feet apart or anytime youâre inside with people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.
Socializing for children is important for their development and wellbeing. There are ways children can socialize but still stay safe and keep from getting and spreading COVID-19.
Find more resources for families with children and information from the CDC for children, teens and young adults.
You can find information about cases across age groups along with other COVID-19 data on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. More detailed information is in the weekly summaries of Vermont COVID-19 data, which include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

question: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
answer:
The challenge with dentistry is the generation of aerosols as part of many office-based activities. This includes dental hygiene through a variety of preventive, restorative, endodontic, periodontic and orthodontic procedures.
Dental health care professionals can resume all procedures, including those that generate aerosol. Read the Interim Guidance for Resuming Dental Services in Vermont.
Dentists and other health care providers must continue to be available to their patients as needed for emergencies and urgent care.
Find more information for health care professionals.

question: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
answer:
Isolation is when people with COVID-19 stay home, and away from other people, until they have recovered, to prevent further spread. Learn about the timeline for people with COVID-19 (with symptoms and without symptoms) from being exposed to being released from isolation.
If you test positive for COVID-19, the Health Department's team of expert contact tracers will call you to provide guidance and information on staying home. They will also ask you about your close contacts. Contact tracers call your close contacts to make sure they know to stay home and quarantine to prevent further spread. Learn more about the timeline for close contacts, from when they have may have been exposed, to when they can end quarantine.
Learn more about isolation, quarantine and self-observation and what to do if you have COVID-19.

question: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
If you or a family member are sick, follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and your community:

Stay home except to get medical care.
Separate yourself from other people.
Monitor your symptoms.
Call ahead before visiting your doctor.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering when youâre around people and pets.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with your sleeve or a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Wash your hands often. Use an alcohol-based sanitizer if soap and water aren't available.
Avoid sharing personal household items.
Clean all high-touch surfaces in your home daily.

Find more details on what to do if you are sick from the CDC.
Find out what to do if you are diagnosed with COVID-19.

question: How many people have recovered from COVID-19 in Vermont?
answer:
The total number of people who have recovered from COVID-19 is updated daily on the Vermont Dashboard. You can find information on how the data for total people recovered are reported in the notes section of the dashboard. There are also more frequently asked questions about the data above the dashboard.
Weekly Data Summaries include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

question: If I go on vacation, do I need to quarantine before I return to work?
answer:
If you travel toÂ certain counties with low rates of active casesÂ ("green"Â counties), you do not need to quarantine.
If you travel to a âredâ or âyellowâ county, then you need to quarantine for 14 days, either before you come back to Vermont or upon your return to Vermont. This applies to both employees living in Vermont and employees who live in a neighboring state and commute to Vermont for work.
If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
Your employer may provide sick or vacation time for you to complete your quarantine.
Find more information on returning to Vermont.

question: How many people who have tested positive for COVID-19 are in my town or county?
answer:
The number of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 by county is updated daily on the Vermont Dashboard.
The number of Vermonters who have tested positive for COVID-19 by the town where they live is updated weekly on the map of cases by town.
When looking at the county or town numbers, please remember that low or no recent cases is not the same as âsafer.â We know the virus is in our communities, and we should continue to follow health guidance to slow the spread of COVID-19 â no matter where we live in or visit. The maps reflect the number of people who had a positive test. There may be people in your county or town that have COVID-19 but have not been tested.
Weekly Data Summaries include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

question: What is the percent of tests positive for COVID-19 in Vermont?
answer: You can find the percent of positive tests, or positivity rate, in Vermont on the Vermont Dashboard.

question: Are there any travel restrictions into Vermont? Are out-of-state visitors allowed?
answer:
If you are visiting or returning to Vermont you must quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. Staying in and completing quarantine is extremely important to help keep people from spreading the virus when they may not know they have it. We strongly encourage you to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
You can either:

Quarantine in your home state for 14 days before coming to Vermont if you are driving in your personal vehicle (including a rental vehicle or private plane) OR
Quarantine at a Vermont lodging facility or home for 14 days if you are traveling by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.

If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result. You must remain in quarantine until you travel to Vermont.
Limit your stops when traveling to Vermont, and only stop when necessary (for example, for fuel, food or rest).
When you stop, follow the general prevention steps: stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with, wear a face mask, avoid crowded indoor spaces, and wash your hands often. Stay home and do not travel if you are sick.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

question: Are campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts open?
answer:
Lodging facilities â hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts, inns, short-term rentals (for example, VRBO, Homeaway, Airbnb, etc.), and all public and private camping facilities, RV parks, seasonal resorts and marinas â may accept overnight reservations from Vermont residents and those who have met the quarantine requirement. Find details and up-to-date information on lodging, campgrounds and other accommodations from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD).
All guests must complete a health questionnaire upon check-in and must provide a Vermont driverâs license or sign a Certificate of Compliance certifying that they met the quarantine requirement or have traveled from a "green" county. Out-of-state guests are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert â a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for symptoms of COVID-19 â for daily reminders from the Vermont Department of Health.
Find more travel and quarantine information from the Health Department and answers to frequently asked questions about travel from the ACCD.
If you have a concern about lodging facilities that are violating the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order, fill out the Department of Public Safety's online non-compliance complaint form.

question: Is it okay to travel within the United States? Do I need to quarantine when I return?
answer:
COVID-19 cases and deaths have been reported in all 50 states and are rising. Travel increases your chances of getting and spreading COVID-19.
Staying home is the best way to protect yourself and others from getting sick. Donât travel if you are sick or if you have been around someone with COVID-19. Donât travel with someone who is sick. Read about travel during the COVID-19 pandemic if you are thinking of traveling away from your local community.
If you travel out of Vermont whether for a day trip or longer, you must quarantine in Vermont for 14 days when you return. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
If you are visiting outside Vermont for a longer period, and you will travel back to Vermont in a personal vehicle (including a rental vehicle or private plane), you may complete either a 14-day quarantine or if you have not had any symptoms of COVID-19, a 7-day quarantine followed by a negative PCR test in the state where you are visiting. Continue to quarantine from when you receive your test result until you travel to Vermont. You may then enter Vermont without further quarantine restrictions.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do when you return to Vermont.

question: I have a second home or a seasonal home in Vermont. Can I come to Vermont?
answer:
If you are returning to your second or seasonal home in Vermont, you are required to quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. Staying in and completing quarantine is extremely important to help keep people from spreading the virus when they may not know they have it. We strongly encourage you to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
You can either:

Quarantine in your home state for 14 days before coming to Vermont if you are driving in your personal vehicle (including a rental vehicle or private plane) OR
Quarantine at a Vermont lodging facility or home for 14 days if you are traveling by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.

If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result. You must remain in quarantine until you travel to Vermont.
Limit your stops when traveling to Vermont, and only stop when absolutely necessary (for example, for fuel, food or rest).
When you stop, follow the general prevention steps: stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with, wear a face mask, avoid crowded indoor spaces, and wash your hands often. Stay home and do not travel if you are sick.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

question: Are mass gatherings (ceremonies, events, fairs or festivals) allowed?
answer:
As Vermont sees a significant surge of new COVID-19 cases across the state, Vermonters are prohibited from gathering with people from other households beginning November 14, 2020. This includes both inside and outside social gatherings, and in public and private spaces. People who live alone may gather with members of their immediate family living in a different household. Read Governor ScottâsÂ Executive Order.
Information on large events, such as weddings, funerals, parties, concerts and sporting events is available from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development. Learn more about wedding ceremonies.
Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of getting or spreading COVID-19.
All traditional fairs and festivals have been canceled until further notice.
Organized outdoor markets, like flea markets, must follow the farmers market guidance from the Agency of Agriculture, Food & Markets (AAFM).
Farmers markets and pick-your-own farms and orchards must follow best practices outlined by AAFM.
Libraries, galleries, museums, theaters and other indoor arts, culture and entertainment organizations are open with certain occupancy limits and health and safety precautions.
Find more information on the health and safety requirements for sectors that are open from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.

question: What does close contact mean?
answer:
Close contact means being within 6 feet, for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period, of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 during their infectious period. The infectious period starts two days before any symptoms began â or for people with COVID-19 who don't have symptoms, two days before they got tested â and continues until they are recovered.
Close contact does not mean being more than 6 feet away in the same indoor environment for a short period of time, walking by, or briefly being in the same room with someone.
Here are some examples:
Examples of close contacts:

You live in the same home.
You are intimate partners.
You rode in the same car while the person was infectious.
You had dinner together while the person was infectious.

Examples of not close contacts:

You were their cashier at the grocery store.
You were their server at a restaurant.
You are a pharmacist who gave the person medication.
You were in front of the person in line at the store.
You are a coworker who briefly walked by to ask a question.

If you are identified as a close contact,Â you will be contacted. The notification could come from the Health Department, your employer, school, or health care provider, for example.Â TheyÂ will call you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home. Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.
Consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

question: Do I need to quarantine if someone I live with is waiting for their COVID-19 test results?
answer:
You do not need to quarantine if you live with someone who is waiting for their test results only if you:

do not have symptoms of COVID-19.
have not had contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.
have not traveled out of Vermont for the past 14 days.

This means that you can go to school, work, or the grocery store.
Be sure to stay at least 6 feet from the person who is under quarantine. People who are under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.
If you have symptoms of COVID-19, talk with your health care provider. If you don't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearestÂ federally qualified health centerÂ or one ofÂ Vermont's free & referral clinics.

question: Can we still have our wedding ceremony?
answer:
As Vermont sees a significant surge of new COVID-19 cases across the state, Governor ScottâsÂ Executive Order prohibits gathering with people from other households as of November 14, 2020.Â This includes social gatherings that are inside and outside, in public and private spaces, as well as any gatherings that are incidental to ceremonies, holiday gatherings, parties and celebrations. People who live alone may gather with members of their immediate family living in a different household.
Find up-to-date information on wedding ceremonies, including the number of people that are allowed, from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.
If you or your guests are visiting Vermont, you must quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
If you have not hadÂ symptoms of COVID-19, you have theÂ optionÂ to get a PCR test on day 7Â and end your quarantine with a negative test result. You must remain in quarantine until you travel to Vermont.
There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.
Whenever possible, keep ceremonies outdoors. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

question: Are bars and restaurants open?
answer:
Restaurants are open under certain health and safety requirements. Restaurants must close in-person dining at 10 p.m., but may provide curbside and delivery service after 10 p.m. For in-person dining, restaurants must seat only one household per table.
Bars and social clubs are closed for in-person service until further notice. Curbside and delivery service is allowed.
Find more details and up-to-date information about restaurants, catering, food service and bars from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

question: What are the long-term health effects of COVID-19?
answer:
The CDC is working to learn more about the whole range of short- and long-term health effects associated with COVID-19. Many organs besides the lungs are affected by COVID-19, and there are many ways the infection can affect someoneâs health.
While most people with COVID-19 recover and return to normal health, some can have symptoms that can last for weeks or even months after their recovery. Even people who are not hospitalized and who have a mild illness can experience persistent or late symptoms. Studies are being done to learn more.
Find out what the long-term health symptoms and complications of COVID-19 are from the CDC.

question: What if there is a case of COVID-19 in school?
answer:
The Health Department quickly responds every time we receive a positive test result for COVID-19. Schools are encouraged to call the Health Department when learning of a positive test result.
The Health Department will:

Contact the person who tested positive (or their parent/guardian), ask them questions about their recent activities and who theyâve been in close contact with, and give instructions on staying home.
Notify the school if the person who tested positive is associated with a school.
Schools do not need to take action if the Health Department determines that there is no risk of further spread at the school. For example, if the person with COVID-19 was not at school during their infectious period, there would not have been an opportunity to spread the virus to others at school.
Work closely with the school to identify close contacts at school (within 6 feet for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period) of the person who tested positive with COVID-19 during their infectious period.
Discuss next steps with school administration, including whether to temporarily close the classroom for in-person instruction. These decisions are made on a case by case basis. The Health Department will provide guidance based on a number of factors, including the level of community transmission, the number of students or staff infected, the status of contact tracing, the number of days the infectious person was at school, infection control policies and practices, the number and structure of classes, pods, or grades affected, and other opportunities for transmission, like extra-curricular activities.

The school will:

Close off any areas where the person spent longer than 15 minutes (like a classroom, gym, or a cafeteria) then clean and disinfect the areas.
Communicate with parents and staff about the situation.
Support the Health Departmentâs efforts by notifying people associated with the school who have been identified as close contacts. The school will provide them with Health Department guidance and information on quarantine and testing. Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for up to 14 days.
Make sure that anyone who tests positive for COVID-19 stays home from school (isolation) until they can return. Find out what to do if you test positive for COVID-19.
Make sure that anyone who had close contact with someone with COVID-19 while they were infectious stays home from school (quarantine) until they can return. Find out what to do if you are a close contact.

For more information:

Learn more about theÂ Health Department's response to COVID-19 cases.
Find a table showing the number of COVID-19 cases in Vermont K-12 schools while infectious, by school name.
Several resources for school administrators, nurses and COVID-19 coordinators are available on the Health Department'sÂ PreK-12 Schools web pageÂ including a quick reference guide for whenÂ someone with COVID-19 was at school while infectious.
Learn about when your child can return to school after being sick.

question: What is an outbreak of COVID-19?
answer:
The Health Department refers to âsituationsâ when one person who tested positive for COVID-19 was at a setting (for example, at school, their work place, or a health care facility) or an event (for example, a private party) while they were infectious and there is a concern that the virus could spread to others who attended the event or who were present at the setting. Situations usually require more follow up than only notifying close contacts. The Health Department monitors situations but does not report any data on them.
However, a situation may become an outbreak. An outbreak means that the virus has spread to more than one person associated with the setting or the event. Learn more about what an outbreak means, when they are considered resolved, how many have happened in each type of setting, plus find more data on outbreaks that have happened in Vermont in our Weekly Data Summary.

question: I am in isolation because I tested positive for COVID-19, but I can't avoid close contact with someone I take care of. Do they need to quarantine?
answer: Yes. In situations where you have COVID-19 (for example, youâre a parent) and you cannot avoid close contact with those you take care of (for example, your children), then the people you take care of should stay home and away from other people while you are sick. They should also quarantine for 14 days after you are able to end home isolation. Learn more about living with someone who has COVID-19 and cannot avoid close contact (Scenario 4).

question: I take care of someone who is in quarantine, but I canât avoid close contact with them. Do I need to quarantine?
answer:
In situations where close contact cannot be avoided, close contacts of the person under quarantine do not also need to quarantine. For example, if someone under quarantine depends on another person for care and basic needs, and close contact cannot be avoided, the caregiver may continue with activities outside of the home. For example, the caregiver may continue to go to work, school, child care, the grocery store, etc.
As much as possible, continue to practice these prevention steps. Stay at least 6 feet from the person who is under quarantine. People who are under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from others to prevent further spread. Quarantine means staying at a home or dwelling for 14 days since the day they were potentially exposed, before doing any activities outside of the home. People in quarantine should separate themselves from others and check themselves for symptoms.

question: What should businesses and non-profits do?
answer:
Vermont is continuing a phased approach to reopen the economy, balancing overall social and economic wellbeing with preventing a rise in COVID-19 that would set us back.
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) has the resources businesses need on the COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:

A step-by-step reopening guide for businesses
Up-to-date phased restart guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face masks or coverings. Businesses and non-profits may require customers or clients to wear masks.
Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses

Find more health resources for businesses from the Health Department.
The Health Department and Agency of Agriculture do not recommend the use of fogging, fumigation, âelectrostatic or wide-area spraying on hard surfaces to control the spread of COVID-19. These methods, while they can be effective,Â âare unnecessary, do not clean contaminated surfaces. They also may result in chemical exposures to workers and the public. Additionally, the Environmental Protection Agency does not recommend using these methods to apply disinfectants unless the label specifically states it is appropriate to do so.
The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: I am in quarantine, but I canât avoid close contact with someone I take care of. Do they need to quarantine?
answer:
In situations where close contact cannot be avoided, close contacts of the person under quarantine do not also need to quarantine. For example, if a person depends on someone who is under quarantine for care and basic needs, and close contact cannot be avoided, the person who receives care may continue with activities outside of the home. For example, they may continue to go to work, school, child care, the grocery store, etc.
As much as possible, continue to practice these prevention steps. Stay at least 6 feet from the person who is under quarantine. People who are under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from others to prevent further spread. Quarantine means staying at a home or dwelling for 14 days since the day they were potentially exposed, before doing any activities outside of the home. People in quarantine should separate themselves from others and check themselves for symptoms.

question: What is quarantine?
answer:
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from other people. Quarantine means you need to stay home and away from other people for 14 days. This means you canât do any activities outside of your home, like going to school, work, or out to do errands or recreation. You should separate yourself from others and check for symptoms.
Quarantine is for:

people who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19 (day 1 of your quarantine starts the day after you were last in contact with them)
Vermonters who travel out of state (day 1 of your quarantine starts the day after you return to Vermont)
people with no symptoms who are visiting Vermont (day 1 of your quarantine starts the day after you arrive in Vermont)
people who have gathered with another household (day 1 of your quarantine starts the day after the gathering)

If you have not hadÂ symptoms of COVID-19, you have theÂ optionÂ to get a PCR test on day 7Â and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
Quarantine helps prevent the spread of COVID-19 before a person knows they are sick, or if they are infected with the virus and donât have symptoms.
We strongly encourage anyone in quarantine to sign up forÂ daily symptom check reminders.
Check the latest quarantine guidance for people visiting or returning to Vermont and find answers to travel-related quarantine questions.
Learn more:

What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation
What to do if you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19
Timeline for close contacts of people with COVID-19
Tips about quarantining when you share a home

question: Why are social gatherings prohibited right now?
answer:
Vermont is seeing a surge in new COVID-19 cases. Recent data have shown that social gatherings, both inside and outside, at homes, bars and social clubs, and among sports teams are currently driving outbreaks in Vermont. This is why there are restrictions on social gatherings at this time.
This is what you cannot do:

You are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. This includes all inside and outside social, recreational and entertainment gatherings, and in public and private spaces. For example, this means you cannot go over to a family member or friendâs house or go to a restaurant with someone you donât live with.
Visitors to Vermont cannot gather with Vermonters or with people from another traveling group. This includes sharing lodging with another household or traveling group. Travelers may not stay with a Vermont host or stay in a Vermont lodging establishment or short-term rental with another household. Even if they have completed a quarantine, or intend to quarantine with another household, they may not gather with another household in Vermont.

This is what you can do:

People who live alone may gather with people who live in one other household.
People can take in and shelter those from another household who are living in a dangerous, unhealthy or otherwise unsafe situation.
You can do outdoor fitness activities with one other person from another household. However, both of you must stay at least 6 feet away from each other and wear a mask at all times. For example, you can bike, hike, walk or run with one of your neighbors.
Visitors to Vermont can socialize only with the people they are traveling with.

It is not considered a social gathering if you have contact with someone for less than 15 minutes, you both are wearing masks, and you stay at least 6 feet apart (for example, checking on a neighbor, friend or family member not in your household). You are allowed to come in contact with members of other households in settings that continue to operate â such as schools, workplaces, retail stores, close contact businesses, etc. â as long as all the required health protocols are followed.
Vermont data at this time does not point to dining at restaurants, gyms, or other close contact businesses as drivers of outbreaks, and current safety protocols at these businesses are working. This is why they are remaining open.
We must all do our part to slow the spread, ensure hospitals are not overwhelmed, help schools continue to offer in-person instruction, and keep as many Vermonters working as possible.
We know this is difficult, but hope that as Vermonters follow this guidance, and we can return to the low case numbers we had and ease restrictions once again.
Read Governor Scottâs Executive Order.

question: Why are rates used on the town map, and how are they calculated?
answer:
The rate of recent cases by town map reflects the rate of cases of COVID-19 among Vermont residents per 10,000 people, by town of residence, from the past two weeks. Rates are commonly used because they allow us to compare the number of cases across towns that have different population sizes.
To calculate the rate by town in the last two weeks, we take the number of cases reported in the last two weeks in a town and divide it by that townâs population. That number is multiplied by 10,000 people. This is the rate, or number of cases per 10,000 people.
Use the map to compare how prevalent COVID-19 is in a town over the past two weeks, relative to other towns. The map may help communities assess how their town is doing and take additional actions to prevent the spread of COVID-19 when necessary.
When looking at the town rates, please remember that having a lower rate of recent cases is not the same as âsafer.â We know the virus is in our communities, and we should continue to follow health guidance to slow the spread of COVID-19 â no matter where we live or where we visit. The data reflect the rate of people who had a positive test. There may be people in your town that have COVID-19 but have not been tested.

question: I had COVID-19, received a positive antibody test, or got a COVID-19 vaccine. Does that mean I am exempt from the travel quarantine or social gathering requirements?
answer:
The Governorâs executive orders do not exempt people who had COVID-19, received a positive antibody test, or got the COVID-19 vaccine. This means that even if you had COVID-19, received a positive antibody test, or got a COVID-19 vaccine, you must quarantine when you travel or return to Vermont under the current travel guidelines. This also means that you are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with under the current social gathering guidelines.
It is not yet known if people who recover from COVID-19 can get infected again. There are no confirmed reports to date of a person being reinfected with COVID-19 within three months of initial infection.
Additionally, if you have received a positive antibody test, that does not mean you have âproof of immunityâ from COVID-19.
It is also not yet known if people who get a COVID-19 vaccine can still infect others with the virus. Find up-to-date information about the COVID-19 vaccine.
Currently, we recommend that everyone, including people who had COVID-19, received a positive antibody test, or got the COVID-19 vaccine continue to follow the prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

question: What information is available for long-term care facilities and other facilities that serve older Vermonters (group homes, nursing homes, assisted living, and state therapeutic care residences)?
answer:
Facilities may offer visitation with residents. Check with the facility first before planning a visit. Medically necessary personnel and visitors for residents receiving end-of-life care are allowed inside. Read the executive order.
Long-term care facilities are following guidance from the Department of Aging and Independent Living (DAIL). Check with the long-term care facility to find out what restrictions are in place.
There is a table showing active outbreaks in long-term care facilities, which is updated on Tuesdays and Fridays.
The Health Department recommends surveillance testing at long-term care facilities to identify people with COVID-19 and to help stop outbreaks in long-term care facilities.
The Health Department recommends that all health care personnel in long-term care facilities and other congregate care settings where health care is provided wear face masks, regardless of the presence of COVID-19 in the facility.
COVID-19 activity in the community may affect how facilities and providers make decisions about testing, operations and personal protective equipment (PPE). Find information for health care providers, nursing homes and other long-term care facilities to make decisions based on measures of community-level burden.
Residents and staff of congregate care settings and new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine period. Testing out of quarantine after day 7 is not an option unless alternate guidance is provided by the Health Department.
See the reopening guidance from DAIL regarding senior centers and adult day centers.
There is guidance Â­on preventing the spread of COVID-19 for managers and owners of senior living communities, which includes making a plan, preparing common spaces and communicating with residents/staff, in addition to outlining the role of the Health Department.
Find more guidance and information for long-term care and group living settings.

question: Can I volunteer to help with the Stateâs response to COVID-19?
answer:
Yes! We are in need of nurses and caregivers for both paid and volunteer positions. Additionally, we need people who can help keep our essential infrastructure operational. We need people from across different sectors and disciplines to assist. There are several ways to become involved. As our needs will change over time, be sure to check back often.
Find paid or volunteer opportunities.
Vermont has eased licensing requirements for the purpose of helping out with the COVID-19 response. Learn more about getting a temporary license if you are a health professional.
Here are other ways you can help:

Donate blood with the American Red Cross.
Support your local Foodbank by volunteering or donating online, or you can text GIVEHEALTH to 85511.
Donate or volunteer with community organizations or emergency supply efforts.
Help your neighbors â older adults and people of any age who have underlying medical conditions should stay close to home as much as possible. Go shopping for a neighbor or someone else in need, keep an older neighbor company by phone or at a safe distance.

When volunteering please follow the guidelines on being a good neighbor.

question: How are the Governorâs executive orders being enforced?
answer:
Enforcement of the Governorâs executive orders â Be Smart, Stay Safe â is mainly done through education and voluntary compliance. Law enforcement officers are encouraged to talk to people or businesses if they see or are made aware of possible violations.

The orders do not close roads, do not establish roadblocks or checkpoints, and do not require people to show their identification.
People may be out and about. Motor vehicles with Vermont and out-of-state registrations are allowed to operate.
There will be no motor vehicle stops and no people detained for questioning about their travel.

If you have a concern about businesses, lodging establishments, short-term rental properties, nonprofits, other entitiesÂ that are violating the Governorâs orders or people who are not quarantining as required, call your local law enforcement agency or file a report online.

question: Are sports and outdoor activities allowed?
answer:
We encourage Vermonters to go outside and enjoy the fresh air. Exercise, outdoor activities, and taking in Vermontâs natural beauty are important for our minds and bodies.
Businesses, facilities and organizations that support or offer outdoor recreation and outdoor fitness activities with low or no direct physical contact are open under certain health and safety requirements. These include, but are not limited to, state parks, municipal parks, recreation associations, pools, beaches, play structures or playgrounds, trail networks, golf courses, big game check stations and guided expeditions.
Indoor and outdoor social gatherings are prohibited, but you can do outdoor fitness activities with one other person from another household. However, both of you must stay at least 6 feet away from each other and wear a mask at all times. For example, you can bike, hike, walk or run with one of your neighbors.
Find up-to-date information from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) on:

outdoor recreation and fitness
sports and organized sports
ski resorts
campgrounds

Hereâs how we can safely continue to enjoy outdoor activities:

Stay close to home. Find local outdoor recreation areas and consider day trips that are close to home. Only drive with members of your household.
Bring a mask with you. You are required to wear a face mask in public spaces, especially when you cannot stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
Take health and safety precautions. Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with, wash or sanitize your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.
Choose low- or no-contact sports, for example, biking, hiking, horseback riding, tennis, boating and golfing. Outdoor basketball courts may be open to shoot hoops, but contact games are not allowed. Do not share sports equipment with people you donât live with.
Be cautious and choose low-risk activities to avoid injury. This will help lower the burden on our hospitals and health care system.
Respect signs for closed areas, trails and land. Check Trail Finder to see if your trail is currently open before you visit. Call ahead or check websites for information on outdoor recreation facilities before you head out.
Check for ticks and wear an EPA-registered tick repellent. When youâre out walking or spending time in your backyard, remember that ticks are active this time of year. Find out how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.

Find out more about outdoor recreation and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation and the Vermont Fish and Wildlife Department.
Find more tips on preventing COVID-19 and learn more about getting together with friends and family.

question: What is Vermont doing?
answer:
Governor Phil Scott declared a State of Emergency to respond to the COVID-19 pandemicÂ to help ensure Vermont has all the necessary resources to respond to this evolving public health emergency. Find details on all executive orders.
The strategies continue to be updated based on guidance from federal and state public health officials. Find a summary of current strategies on the Governor's website.

question: What is contact tracing?
answer:
Contact tracing is used to provide education, support and guidance to people who are diagnosed with an infectious disease. Itâs also used to identify people who have been in close contact with them, so they can take steps to stop the disease from spreading to others.
If you test positive for COVID-19, you will get a call from the Health Department. A trained public health worker, called a contact tracer, will give you guidance to stay home and away from other people until you recover. This stops the virus from spreading to other people. They will ask you questions about your symptoms, activities, and who you may have come into contact with during a specific period of time. This information is only used to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
If you are identified as a close contact, you will be contacted. The notification will come from the Health Department or a place you went to recently (for example, your employer, your childâs school, or your health care provider might contact you). They will contact you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home.
If you receive a text message from 89361, this is a notification from the Health Department that you are a close contact of someone who tested positive for COVID-19. Soon you will receive a call from a Health Department Contact Tracer. Find out what you need to do if you are a close contact.
Itâs important to answer the call and to answer questions as completely as possible to make sure everyone knows what steps to take to prevent further spread of the virus. Governor Scottâs Executive Order calls on Vermonters to comply with all contact tracing requests.
All restaurants and other businesses are keeping a 30-day log of employee and guest names and contact information in case contact tracing is needed.
Consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.
Currently, Vermont is not participating in the contact tracing notifications that are available on some cell phones. We are waiting to see how successful this service is in other states who are participating. If itâs proven to be effective, we will consider using it.
Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.

question: How can I stay up to date on the latest COVID-19 guidance and information?
answer:
The most current comprehensive guidance and information is on the Health Departmentâs COVID-19 website and the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Recovery Center. You canÂ sign up for the Health Departmentâs Weekly COVID-19 E-Newsletter to get the latest news.
You can also sign up to get notifications from VT-ALERT. VT-ALERT sends important updates to the Governorâs Executive Orders and other related COVID-19 announcements that will directly impact Vermonters. You can get notifications by email, text, phone and the Everbridge mobile app. You can also specify geographic areas (for example, the town or county where you live or work). Once you register for VT-ALERT, select the alerts you would like to get. COVID-19 information is listed under âHealth Alertsâ. If you are already subscribed, you can update your subscriptions after you log in.

question: How many outbreaks are there in long-term care facilities?
answer: You can find a table showingÂ active outbreaks in long-term care facilities. The table will be updated on Tuesdays and Fridays.

question: What is known about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) associated with COVID-19?
answer:
According to the CDC, Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) is a condition where different body parts can become inflamed, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, brain, skin, eyes, or gastrointestinal organs. We do not yet know what causes MIS-C. However, we know that many children with MIS-C had the COVID-19 virus, or had been around someone with COVID-19. Children with MIS-C may have a fever and various symptoms, including abdominal (gut) pain, vomiting, diarrhea, neck pain, rash, bloodshot eyes, or feeling extra tired. MIS-C can be serious, even deadly, but most children who were diagnosed with this condition have gotten better with medical care.
MIS-C is rare, and it remains unknown whether multisystem inflammatory syndrome only occurs in children or if it also can occur in adults.
Learn more about Multisystem Inflammatory Disease and COVID-19 from the Health Department.

question: What should communities of faith do?
answer:
For many traditions, gathering together is the heart of a faith-based community. Gatherings can increase the risk of spreading COVID-19, so it's important to follow public health guidelines to keep communities safeÂ while keeping traditions alive.
Religious facilities and places of worship can operate under certain health and safety requirements from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD). Find out what actions congregates, attendees, and organizations leaders and staff can take to stay safe.

question: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
answer:
When someone tests positive for COVID-19, the Health Department works with them to identify their close contacts. Generally, these are people you were within 6 feet of, for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period, during the time they were infectious (contagious).
If you are identified as a close contact, you will be contacted. The notification will come from the Health Department or a place you went to recently (for example, your employer, your childâs school, or your health care provider might contact you). They will contact you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home.
If you receive a textÂ message from 89361, this is a notification from the Health Department that you are a close contact of someone whoÂ tested positive for COVID-19. Soon you will receive a call from aÂ Health Department Contact Tracer.Â Find out what you need to do if you are a close contact.
If you are not identified as a close contact, then you will not be called. While contact tracers work to identify all close contacts, all might not be identified. If you think that you might be a close contact but didn't get a call, you may take precautions by quarantining for 14 days since the last day you were in contact with that person, and get tested on day 7 or after if you have not had any symptoms.
If you are not a close contact of a person who tested positive, you can continue to follow the prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.
Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.

question: Can I come to Vermont to ski?
answer:
Vermont ski areas will open this season under mandatory health and safety guidelines, which include limits on lift and lodge capacities. If you come to Vermont to ski or snowboard, you must attest that you completed Vermontâs quarantine requirements.
That means you must quarantine for 14 days before coming to Vermont. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result. You must remain in quarantine until you travel to Vermont.
You will also be required to give your contact information to the ski resort in case contact tracing is needed.
You are required to wear a mask when you are in a lodge and anytime you are in a public space. Try to avoid crowded places as much as possible and stay at least 6 feet away from people you didnât travel with.
As of November 14, 2020, you are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. This includes all inside and outside social, recreational and entertainment gatherings, and in public and private spaces. This means that visitors to Vermont can only socialize with the people they are traveling with. They cannot gather with Vermonters or with people from another traveling group. Learn more about what this means.
Be sure to check with the ski resort before you plan your trip to find out any other rules that the resort has.
Find more travel and quarantine information.

question: Are there any recommendations for older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions?
answer:
According to the CDC, the risk for severe illness from COVID-19 increases with age, with older adults at highest risk, and is higher for people of any age with certain underlying medical conditions. Severe illness means that the person with COVID-19 may require hospitalization, intensive care, or a ventilator to help them breathe, or they may even die.
If you are in one of these groups, take these extra precautions in addition to the COVID-19 prevention steps:

Stay close to home as much as possible. Traveling out of state is not recommended since the virus is still widespread in neighboring states and across the country.
Be aware of your surroundings. Choose outdoor settings over indoor settings. Pay attention to the size of the space, crowding, the number of people there, and if they are wearing face coverings and keeping a 6-foot distance.
Choose activities that donât require close contact. Minimize close contact while talking or doing anything that requires exertion, shouting or singing.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with

The CDC recommends other populations also take extra precautions, like pregnant people, people experiencing homelessness, and people with disabilities.

question: How do I wash or sanitize my hands to keep from getting sick?
answer:
The CDC recommends washing your hands often with soap and water for 20 seconds. To prevent the spread of germs during the COVID-19 pandemic, itâs especially important to wash your hands before and after:

Touching your eyes, nose or mouth
Eating or preparing food
Blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing
Touching your mask
Entering and leaving a public place
Touching an item or surface that may be frequently touched by other people (such as door handles, tables, gas pumps, shopping carts, or electronic cashier registers/screens, etc.)
Caring for someone who is sick

If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. Cover all surfaces of your hands and rub them together until they feel dry. Always wash your hands with soap and water if they look dirty.

question: What is Sara Alert?
answer:
Sara Alert is a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19. Sara Alert is for:

People who test positive for COVID-19
Close contacts of people with COVID-19
People visiting or returning to Vermont

Once you sign up, Sara Alert sends daily reminders until they automatically stop after two weeks. You can choose to receive messages by email, text or phone. If you report symptoms, the Health Department will reach out to provide guidance and next steps.
Sara Alert is not a contact tracing system. It is not GPS-based, so it does not monitor your movements or track your location.
Here are some reasons why you should sign up for Sara Alert:

You get fast, easy, and free reminders to check yourself for symptoms.
You get quick access to the Health Department for guidance and information if you develop symptoms.
It helps our public health teams contain the spread of COVID-19.

If you are a close contact of someone who has COVID-19, you will be given the link to sign up for Sara Alert when you are notified.
If you are visiting Vermont or recently returned to Vermont, learn more about Sara Alert and sign up. Visitors or returning travelers who are currently enrolled in Sara Alert who have questions about their messages can email the Travel Team or call 802-863-7240 (option 6).

question: How can I make my own homemade cloth face mask or covering?
answer:
Homemade cloth face masks or coverings can be made using simple materials found in most homes, for example, an old t-shirt or bandanna and rubber bands or hair ties. Your cloth face mask or covering should include multiple layers of fabric and allow you to be able to breathe easily. Watch a quick video by the CDC on how to make your own cloth face mask.
You are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces (for example, businesses, public buildings, parks), group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes), and other places where itâs not possible to stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
In private settings (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you wear a face mask or covering anytime you're around people you donât live with.
Learn more:

Wearing face masks to keep COVID-19 from spreading
Face coverings for children
How to select, clean and wear your face mask

The State of Vermont is offering a limited number of free cloth face masks to the public. Find out if free cloth face masks are available in your area.

question: What is the difference between COVID-19 and the flu?
answer:
Influenza (flu) and COVID-19 are both contagious respiratory illnesses, but they are caused by different viruses. COVID-19 is caused by infection with a new coronavirus (called SARS-CoV-2) and flu is caused by infection with influenza viruses.
Because some of the symptoms of flu and COVID-19 are similar, it may be hard to tell the difference between them based on symptoms alone, and testing may be needed to help confirm a diagnosis. Flu and COVID-19 share many characteristics, but there are some key differences between the two:

COVID-19 seems to spread more easily than flu and causes more serious illnesses in some people.
It can take longer before people show symptoms of COVID-19, and people can be contagious with the COVID-19 virus for longer.

Doctors and scientists are working to estimate the death rate of COVID-19, but currently, it is thought to be substantially higher (possibly 10 times or more) than that of most strains of the flu.
Find more information about the differences and similarities between flu and COVID-19 from the CDC.
Itâs more important than ever to get your flu shot this year, when flu viruses and the new coronavirus may be spreading at the same time. Learn more about the flu and find a flu shot.
Find out more about what Vermont is doing to prepare for a COVID-19 vaccine.
There are things you can do to keep from getting or spreading the flu and COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.

question: Are face masks or coverings required in Vermont?
answer:
You are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces (for example, businesses, public buildings, parks), group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes), and other places where itâs not possible to stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
Face masks or coverings are not required when you are doing strenuous exercise or activities. They are also not required for â and should not be worn by:

Children under the age of 2
Anyone who has trouble breathing
Anyone who is unable to remove the face mask without assistance
Anyone who has a medical or behavioral reason for not wearing a face mask

If you have a medical or developmental condition or have trouble breathing, you are not required to show evidence or documentation of your condition.
Businesses and other entities may also post signage explaining their mask requirements and can deny entry or service to people who are not wearing a mask, including people who are not required to wear a mask. However, the business must provide another way for people who are unable to wear a mask to access the business (for example, offering curbside pick-up or delivery or other creative solution).
In private settings (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you wear a face mask or covering anytime youâre around people you donât live with.
Wearing face masks or coverings helps keep people from spreading the virus. This is because the virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms.
In addition to wearing face masks or coverings, these are things you can do to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.
Learn more:

Wearing face masks to keep COVID-19 from spreading
Face coverings for children
How to select, clean and wear your face mask

The State of Vermont is offering a limited number of free cloth face masks to the public. Find out if free cloth face masks are available in your area.why, how and when to do these things

question: When will I receive my test results?
answer:
Test results will be available typically within 3 business days. Find out what to do while youâre waiting for your test results.
How you receive results varies depending on where you were tested.
If you were tested at a Health Department testing site (for people without symptoms) and:

you requested an electronic result, you can expect an email within 3 business days, when your result is ready. You can thenÂ log in to your COVID-19 testing accountÂ to get the result. You will not receive a letter.
you requested a letter, you can expect to receive it within 7 business days. If you also provided an email address, you can expect an email within 3 business days, when your result is ready.Â You can thenÂ log in to your COVID-19 testing accountÂ to get the result.

The Health Department only uses a PCR test.Â We cannot guarantee that you will receive your results in less than 3 business days. We also cannot accommodate special requests for receiving test results. Find the list of Health Department test sites.
If you have a positive result, our contact tracing team will talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.
If you got tested anywhere else, the Health Department cannot provide your results. Please contact your health care provider if they ordered the test, or the facility that conducted the test.
If you were tested before an inpatient or outpatient procedure, you will receive your test results before your procedure from the health care provider who is doing the procedure.
If you received a positive result, the Health Department will also reach out to talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.

question: How is a sample collected for COVID-19 testing?
answer:
Usually, samples (specimens) are collected from you in one of two ways:

Nasal swab - this is a short, dry swab that is used to collect a sample from the front of your nose. This type of test is used at the Health Departmentâs testing sites. It is also used for certain priority groups, including children.
Nasopharyngeal or NP swab â this is a long, dry swab that is inserted through one nostril and is rubbed against the back of your nose and throat.

question: Can my spouse or partner get a COVID-19 vaccine if they are younger than 75?
answer:
No. Only people who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont may make an appointment. Your spouse or partner will be able to get their vaccine as soon as their age group is eligible. People who are 70 years and older will be the next eligible age group.
Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

question: Do I have to be a Vermont resident to get the COVID-19 vaccine?
answer:
Yes. You will need to provide your address to make an appointment for the COVID-19 vaccine. However, if you live in another state, you can still get a vaccine in Vermont if:

You work in Vermont.
Your primary health care provider is in Vermont.
You moved to Vermont within the last 6 months with the intention of becoming a resident.

Identification is not required to make or go to a vaccine appointment.
People who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont are now eligible to get a vaccine. Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.
Find out who will be eligible next.

question: How will I know when I can get my vaccine?
answer:
In the current phase, people who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont are eligible to get a vaccine.
In Phase 1A, health care workers and long-term care residents and staff are being notified directly about when and where they can get vaccinated. Because vaccine supply fluctuates, at this time health care personnel may have to wait for the next opportunity when there is more vaccine available. Check with your local hospital for updates.
In addition to Health Department communications, we will work with partners such as health care practices, pharmacies, employers, and local news media to announce how people who are eligible can make an appointment.
The Health Department is not keeping a list of eligible people. As each group becomes eligible, we will announce when those people can register for appointments. In addition to Health Department communications, we will work with partners such as health care practices, pharmacies, employers, and local news media to announce additional groups who become eligible for the vaccine.

question: When will the next group be eligible for a vaccine?
answer: We still have a very limited number of doses we receive each week. The number we receive each week can change. Vaccinations for those who are age 75 and older will begin on January 27 and include about 49,000 Vermonters. This will likely take about 6 weeks or more to complete. Because this estimate is based on the number of doses we receive, it could change.

question: Who will be eligible next?
answer:
