In addition to ongoing vaccination of health care workers and residents and staff of long-term care facilities, Vermont is usingÂ age groupingsÂ to determine who can receive the vaccine next based on our primary goal with vaccination efforts â to save lives.
Currently, only those age 75 and older are eligible to receive the vaccine. There are no exceptions based on age, chronic condition, circumstances of employment, or any other factor. In the weeks and months to come, age-based criteria will expand to include those age 70 and older, followed by those age 65 and older. When that population has been vaccinated, Vermonters with specific chronic conditions will be included.
After the age groups, the vaccine will be available to people in Vermont who have certain high-risk health conditions. These are medical conditions that put them at increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19 as identified by the CDC. These are:

Current cancer
Chronic kidney disease
COPD, also called emphysema
Heart conditions, such as heart failure, coronary artery disease, or cardiomyopathies
Immunocompromised state (weakened immune system)
Severe obesity
Pregnancy
Type 2 diabetes mellitus
Down Syndrome
Sickle cell disease

Stay tuned to our website for updates on the next phases.

question: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
answer:
The virus is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person. Here is how you can protect yourself from getting COVID-19 and from spreading it to others:

Stay home and away from others if you are sick.
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol, especially after being in a public place, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with. If you are around other people, itâs safest to be outdoors.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.
Have the âCOVID Talkâ with people before you make plans and share what you need to feel safe and comfortable.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Avoid crowded indoor spaces.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the inside of your elbow. Throw the tissue in the trash and wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily.
Limit your travel. Check Vermont's travel guidance, and read CDC's guidance on travel in the United States.

Learn more:

Preventing COVID-19
Daily activities and going out
How to help care for someone sick at home
How to protect yourself and others

question: Can I register to get the COVID-19 vaccine now? How do I sign up?
answer:
The current phase of vaccination is only for people who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont. Appointments are required, and clinics won't be able to accept walk-ins.
You will need to create an account in the registration system first, and then log in to schedule your appointment. You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address.
If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The registration system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system. Even if youâre not currently eligible to get a vaccine, you can set up an account ahead of time.
Find out what you will need and how to make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine. You can also watch a video on how to make your appointment online.
If you are eligible, talk with your health care provider if you've had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine, injectable therapy, or polysorbate, or if you have questions about whether getting the vaccine is right for you because of health conditions, allergies, or other vaccines you've received recently. Read the health screening questions asked before you get the vaccine.
For more information:

How to make a vaccine appointment for someone else
What to do if you have problems scheduling a vaccine appointment
What to expect at your vaccine appointment
Frequently asked questions about vaccine registration and appointments
Who will be eligible next to get the vaccine

question: Can I make a vaccine appointment for someone else? How do I sign someone up as a dependent?
answer:
Yes, you can make an appointment for your loved one or someone you care for who is 75 years or older, especially if they need help registering online.
If you are making an appointment online for a spouse or partner at the same time as your own, you will need to make the appointments individually. Learn more about making two appointments at the same time.
If you are a case worker who is scheduling an appointment for your client, please call 855-722-7878 Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.
If you are scheduling an appointment for a family member, we recommend that you create an account, and then sign them up as a âdependent.â
First, you need to create an account in the registration system. You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address.
If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The registration system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system. If you already have an account, go to the âadding them as a dependentâ steps below.
Here is how you create an account:

Go to the COVID-19 Event Portal.
Enter your name, phone number, email address, and date of birth.
Click the âcreate accountâ button.

After you create an account, an email is immediately sent to the email address you entered. You will need to verify your account on the COVID-19 Event Portal to make the personâs appointment:

Click on the link in the email sent to you to verify your account.
Enter your Patient ID number.
Create a password.
Review and consent to the Notice of Privacy Practices.
Enter your personal information.

Next, you need to add them as a dependent. Click on the âAdd Dependent/Spouseâ button at the top of the screen. After consenting, you will need to enter their personal information:

Name
Email address (use your email, the same one used to set up your account)
Phone number
Date of birth
Address

If the person getting the vaccine does not live in Vermont, the system will ask do they work in Vermont, get primary care in Vermont, or recently moved to Vermont. If none of these apply, they wonât be able to get vaccinated in Vermont, and should seek a vaccine in the state where they live.
Then, click the âSchedule Vaccine Appointmentâ button at the top of the screen and select their name. Select a clinic site location by searching by county and date range.
Next, you will answer a series of medical (see below) and demographic questions as well as questions about any COVID-19 symptoms the person has. You will be asked to provide their health insurance information. Insurance is not required, and there is no cost for getting the vaccine. You will be asked to complete a waiver.
Finally, choose an appointment slot from the list of available appointments. Click the âsubmitâ button. You will immediately receive an email confirmation.
These are the medical screening questions asked:

Have you ever had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine or injectable therapy, an immediate allergic reaction of any severity to a previous dose of an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine or any of its components (including polyethylene glycol [PEG]), or an immediate allergic reaction of any severity to polysorbate? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get any of the currently available COVID-19 vaccines. They should consider contacting their health care provider if they have questions.
Are you currently sick with COVID-19 or still in your isolation period following a COVID-19 infection? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a COVID-19 vaccine at this time, but can schedule an appointment at a later date.
Have you received another vaccine in the last 14 days? If the answer is yes, then they won't be able to schedule an appointment right now, but can log back in at a later date to schedule an appointment.
Do you have a weakened immune system caused by something such as HIV infection or cancer or do you take immunosuppressive drugs or therapies? If the answer is yes, then they can make an appointment but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
Do you have a history of a bleeding disorder or are you taking a blood thinner? If the answer is yes, then they can still get a vaccine, but they may want to talk with their health care provider first about any concerns. People with bleeding disorders or who are taking blood thinners may bruise or have more serious bleeding after injections. Special precautions can be taken to help avoid post-injection bleeding and bruising, such as using a very fine needle and applying pressure to the injection site after the injection.
Are you pregnant? If the answer is yes, then they can make an appointment but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
Are you breastfeeding or lactating? If the answer is yes, then they can make an appointment but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
Have you received passive antibody therapy as treatment for COVID-19 in the past 90 days? If the answer is yes, then they will need to wait for 90 days before scheduling an appointment.

You can also watch a video on how to make an appointment online.

question: Can I make two appointments for COVID-19 vaccination at the same time, for example for both my parents or myself and my spouse?
answer:
You will need to register each person individually. We can only register one person for an appointment at a time online and through the call center. This is because each slot and series of questions apply just to one person.
If you are making an appointment online, you can either create an account for each person, or create a single account and add the other person to the account by clicking on the âAdd Dependent/Spouseâ button at the top of the screen (follow the prompts in the registration system). You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address. Find out what you will need and how to make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.
If you are making an appointment by phone, you can also make more than one appointment. We will do our best to get the appointments as close together as possible, but they may not be at the same time. Call 855-722-7878 Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.

question: What should businesses do to protect workers and customers?
answer:
Current information is on the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:

Up-to-date guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face masks or coverings. Businesses and non-profits may require customers or clients to wear masks.
Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses

More resources are available from the Health Department:

Health guidance and resources for businesses and employees
What to do if an employee tests positive for COVID-19
What to do if a guest or visitor at your establishment tests positive for COVID-19
Checklist for Employers: COVID-19 in the Workplace
COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses
Best Practices for Retail Food Stores, Restaurants, and Food Pick-Up/Delivery Services During the COVID-19 Pandemic from the Food and Drug Administration.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: Do I need to bring identification to my vaccine appointment?
answer:
No. Identification is not required to make or go to a vaccine appointment.
When you sign up for your appointment, you will be asked to provide your:

Name
Date of birth
Address
Email (if available)
Phone number
Health insurance information (helpful but not required)

Learn more about if you are not a Vermont resident.

question: Do I need to use the same account I made to get a COVID-19 test to schedule a vaccine appointment?
answer:
If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The registration system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system.
Once you log in, click on the âSchedule Vaccine Appointmentâ button at the top of the screen and follow the prompts on the screen. You can also watch a video on how to schedule an appointment.

question: What do owners of lodging facilities need to do?
answer:
Lodging operations, short-term rentals, campgrounds and marinas may accept overnight reservations from Vermont residents and out-of-state guests who have met the quarantine requirement.
Lodging operators should recommend that all out-of-state guests sign up with Sara Alert once arriving in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.
Find details on the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:

Up-to-date phased restart guidance for lodging, campgrounds and other accommodations. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face masks or coverings over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.
Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses

Read the COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses and find more resources for food and lodging businesses from the Health Department.
Find out what to do if a guest or visitor at your establishment tests positive for COVID-19 from the Health Department.
The Vermont State Police and local law enforcement will continue to do compliance checks at lodging establishments.
The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: Which businesses are open?
answer:
Vermont is continuing a phased approach to reopen the economy, balancing overall social and economic wellbeing with preventing a rise in COVID-19 that would set us back.
Find current information on the health and safety requirements for businesses, non-profit and government operations that are open and frequently asked questions from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
Businesses can find a step-by-step guide to reopening and up-to-date phased restart guidance from the ACCD.
Find the most recent Governorâs Executive Orders for more information.

question: Which vaccine should I get? Will I have a choice?
answer:
Both the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are more than 94% effective with similar side effects. Side effects are a normal way that your body builds immunity to COVID-19.
Which vaccine you get will most likely be based on which vaccine is available at your appointment. As time goes on, you may have a choice, especially if ongoing studies determine if one is better for certain people, like for children.
For your second dose, you should get the same vaccine as your first dose. When you are at your first vaccine appointment, someone will help you schedule an appointment to get your second dose of vaccine. You will also be given a card with the name of the vaccine you received when you get your first shot. If you have a smartphone, you may want to take a picture of the card in case you misplace it.

question: Why canât children and adolescents get the COVID-19 vaccine?
answer:
Childrenâs immune systems are different at different ages. They are also different from adults. This means that the vaccine studies need to be repeated with children. Both Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna have started vaccine trials with children as young as age 12. If the trials are successful, there will be the usual review processes before the vaccines can be approved for emergency use and then produced for distribution. This process can take a while, especially for very young ages, which are usually tested last.
The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is authorized for people 16 years and older. The Moderna vaccine is authorized for people 18 years and older.

question: How can someone make a vaccine appointment if they donât have internet access or don't know how to use a computer?
answer:
Registering online will be the quickest way to make an appointment. If your loved one or someone you care for is 75 years or older, we ask that you help them register online. Find out how to make an appointment for someone else.
If registering online is not an option, you can call 855-722-7878 Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.

question: Where can people get vaccinated?
answer:
People 75 years and older can make an appointment online or by phone. Find out what you will need and how to make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.
Health care workers and long-term care residents and staff are being notified directly about when and where they can get vaccinated. Because vaccine supply fluctuates,Â at this timeÂ health careÂ personnel may have to wait for the next opportunity when there is more vaccine available.Â Check with your local hospital for updates.
For each phase, we will offer vaccines at regional clinics set up by the state. These clinics will be handicap accessible. Some vaccines will be available through our partner hospitals, providers, and pharmacies. Our goal will be to administer every available dose each week. We are also collaborating with community organizations and other partners to make sure people who are disproportionately affected by COVID-19, including Black, Indigenous and people of color, have equitable access to the vaccine.
You can find a map of the areas where vaccination sites are, not actual locations. When you schedule your appointment, you will get the address of the vaccination site you chose.

question: What protections are in place for congregate care settings and long-term care facilities?
answer:
The Health Department has contacted all long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities proactively to review strategies to prevent COVID-19 infection and develop plans to respond immediately if an infection is identified. We complete an in-depth assessment by phone and provide guidance about personal protective equipment and other infection prevention and control recommendations. We continue to stay in touch for any technical assistance needs and additional questions.
If a case of COVID-19 is associated with a long-term care facility, an epidemiology team is quickly activated. They contact the facility to provide recommendations and infection control support. The team begins contact tracing to determine the source of the infection and how it may be spreading. They ask questions and collect information to help identify anyone the patient had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than 6 feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) The team communicates with close contacts to ensure isolation and quarantine guidelines are being followed, which will differ depending on the type of setting.
Vermont is taking measures to slow the spread of COVID-19 in certain types of group living facilities, including nursing homes, assisted living facilities, residential care homes, therapeutic community residences, residential treatment centers, correctional facilities,Â state psychiatric care facilities, and homeless shelters.
If a staff member or resident tests positive for COVID-19, facility-wide testing of staff and residents might be recommended in consultation with the Health Department. If facility-wide testing is recommended, the Health Department provides technical assistance to make sure that the facility is connected with testing resources and provides guidance on when additional rounds of testing should take place. The Health Department also works closely with the facility to provide infection control guidance and resources.
Additionally, many long-term care facilities are conducting ongoing staff surveillance testing. For related guidance, read the Long Term Care Guidance for Operations During COVID-19 Health Emergency from the Department of Disabilities, Aging and Independent Living (DAIL) and Testing Recommendations for Long-term Care Facilities from the Health Department.
There is a table showing active outbreaks in long-term care facilities, which is updated on Tuesdays and Fridays.
Residents and staff of group living facilities and new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine period first.

question: When do I need to get my second shot?
answer:
The COVID-19 vaccine is two shots, 21 or 28 days apart. Both of theÂ vaccines availableÂ are over 94% effective withÂ two doses. Doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine are given 21 days apart, and doses of the Moderna vaccine are given 28 days apart.
For the vaccine to be the most effective and help prevent you from getting COVID-19, you should get your second shot as close to the recommended time interval. If you miss your second dose, please get it as soon as you can.
You won't be able to make an appointment for your second dose until you get your first dose. Before you leave your first dose appointment, clinic staff will help you makeÂ an appointment to get the second dose.

question: What are the ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines?
answer:
The ingredients in the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines are similar to what is found in other vaccines â both contain the mRNA protein, fats, salts, and sugars. They do not have any fetal tissue, animal products, eggs, gelatin, latex, or preservatives in them.
Learn more about which vaccines are available in Vermont.

question: Should I get the vaccine if I have a medical condition?
answer:
In clinical studies, COVID-19 vaccines were just as effective for people with and without medical conditions. In fact, people with some conditions are more likely to get very sick if they get COVID-19, so getting vaccinated could be even more important. If you are unsure if you should get the vaccine, talk to your health care provider about any conditions you have. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
Learn more about vaccination if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Read the health screening questions asked before you get the vaccine.

question: Should I be vaccinated if I have or had COVID-19?
answer:
If you had COVID-19 and are recovered, you may be vaccinated or choose to defer for up to 90 days. Evidence suggests that getting infected again in 90 days after is uncommon.
If you currently have COVID-19, please wait until you have recovered before being vaccinated.
If you had monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma as part of COVID-19 treatment, wait for at least 90 days before getting your vaccination to avoid interfering with your treatment.

question: Iâve received two doses of the vaccine. Do I still need to wear a mask, avoid close contact with others, and quarantine?
answer:
Yes. People who get the vaccine should continue taking steps to prevent COVID-19. It takes time for the vaccine to train your body to fight COVID-19, so you may not be protected by the vaccine until a few weeks after your second dose. While the vaccine protects you from illness, we donât yet know if you can unknowingly spread the virus after you get vaccinated. Until enough people are vaccinated and we know more, we need to follow all safety guidelines like wearing masks, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing our hands.
Even if you have gotten the vaccine, you must quarantine when you travel or return to Vermont under the current travel guidelines. Also, you are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with under the current social gathering guidelines.
It will take a while for everyone to be vaccinated. Together, the vaccine and those preventive actions are the best ways to keep from getting and spreading COVID-19.

question: Iâm in quarantine because I was exposed to someone who was positive for COVID-19. Should I still get the vaccine?
answer: You should wait to get your vaccine until you are able to end your quarantine.

question: I am pregnant or breastfeeding. Should I get vaccinated?
answer:
Based on how mRNA vaccines work, experts believe they are unlikely to pose a specific risk for people who are pregnant. However, the actual risks of mRNA vaccines to the pregnant person and their fetus are unknown because these vaccines have not been studied in pregnant people. Pregnant people have a slightly higher risk for poor outcomes, as do their fetuses, with COVID-19 infection. Studies are on-going.
If you are pregnant and part of a group that is recommended to receive the vaccine (for example, health care personnel), you may choose to be vaccinated. The CDC and other professional organizations recommend that you consult with your health care provider.
There are no data on the safety of COVID-19 vaccines in people who are breastfeeding or the effects of mRNA vaccines on milk production/excretion or on the breastfed baby. mRNA vaccines are not thought to be a risk to the breastfed baby. A person who is breastfeeding and is part of a group recommended to receive a COVID-19 vaccine (for example, health care personnel) may choose to be vaccinated.

question: How much does the COVID-19 vaccine cost?
answer: COVID-19 vaccines are free. COVID-19 vaccines are provided to Vermonters at no cost, even if you donât have health insurance. The provider that gives you your vaccine may charge an administrative fee to your insurance, but you are guaranteed a COVID-19 vaccine without paying a fee.

question: How do I know if my symptoms are from the vaccine or sickness from COVID-19?
answer:
It takes time for the vaccine to teach your body to fight COVID-19, so you may not be protected by the vaccine until a few weeks after your second dose. This is one of the reasons it is so important to continue prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, even after youâve been vaccinated.
It may be hard to tell the difference between side effects from the vaccine and symptoms from sickness if you get infected with COVID-19 between vaccine doses. While everyoneâs reaction may be different, vaccine side effects usually start within 12 to 24 hours after your vaccination. They should go away within a few days.
If symptoms get worse or last longer than a few days, contact your health care provider. They should be able to suggest next steps and maybe a COVID-19 test. Getting the vaccine will not affect your COVID-19 test results.

question: Where can I find the most current information about the COVID-19 vaccine in Vermont?
answer:
Stay up to date on COVID-19 vaccination in Vermont, including who can get the vaccine now and who will be eligible next. Check back often as we update this page regularly. And sign up for our Weekly COVID-19 Update Email to stay up to date.
While we wait for the vaccine to become more widely available to Vermonters, we all must continue to keep up our prevention practices, which are still the best protection from getting and spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

The Health Department also strongly recommends that everyone age 6 months and older get their flu shot. The flu vaccine is available in your doctorâs office and at pharmacies around the state. This will help prevent the potential harm of getting the flu and COVID-19 â at the same time or in succession. Learn more about the flu and find a flu shot.

question: Am I eligible to get the COVID-19 vaccine? Can I get on a list?
answer:
People who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont are now eligible to get a vaccine. Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.
Health care workers and long-term care residents and staff are being notified directly about when and where they can get vaccinated. Because vaccine supply fluctuates, at this time health care personnel may have to wait for the next opportunity when there is more vaccine available. Check with your local hospital for updates.
If you are eligible, talk with your health care provider if you've had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine, injectable therapy, or polysorbate, or if you have questions about whether getting the vaccine is right for you because of health conditions, allergies, or other vaccines you've received recently. Read the health screening questions asked before you get the vaccine.
The Health Department is not keeping a list of eligible people. When there is enough vaccine available, we will be announcing when Vermonters can register for appointments and who is eligible. In addition to Health Department communications, we will work with partners such as health care practices, pharmacies, employers, and local news media to announce additional groups who become eligible for the vaccine.
Find out who will be eligible next.

question: How do I reschedule or cancel my vaccine appointment?
answer:
It is very important that you keep the appointment you made. Please do not make an appointment if you are not sure you will be able to keep it. Cancellations and unplanned no-shows could cause the vaccine to be spoiled.
If you need to cancel your appointment, please do as soon as possible. You will need to log in to your account and cancel it there.
If you need to reschedule your appointment, call 855-722-7878. If you reschedule it online,Â youâll have to cancel your current appointment and may risk not getting an earlier one.

question: What should returning and new college students do?
answer:
Colleges and universities must follow the Mandatory Guidance for College and University Campus Learning. Please contact your college or university directly for information about arriving on campus, testing and health guidance.
The City of Burlington has a Supportive Quarantine Pilot Program. The program includes a move-in care package of fresh local goods, a mask, and hygiene supplies.
Parents or other visitors can find information on traveling to Vermont and quarantine, information on how to drop off someone at college,Â and answers toÂ frequently asked questions about travel.
Find outÂ what happens at the Health Department when someone tests positive for COVID-19.
Find tips for how toÂ enjoy safer sex and reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19 and more resources for college students.

question: I am not able to leave my home. How can I get the vaccine?
answer:
We are currently working on a plan to make sure people who are unable to leave their home can get a COVID-19 vaccine. We hope to work with emergency medical services agencies across Vermont to provide in-home vaccinations to people who need it.
These in-home vaccine visits havenât started yet, and probably wonât be ready in the next phase of vaccine distribution, but we are working hard to make this possible and will put more information on our website as soon as possible.

question: What is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?
answer:
You are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces (for example, businesses, public buildings, parks), group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes), and other places where itâs not possible to stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
In private settings (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you wear a mask anytime you're around people you donât live with.
People with COVID-19 can spread the virus even if they donât have any symptoms. Masks protect others around you as well as offer some protection to you.
A mask must be worn properly to be effective and avoid spreading the virus:

Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer before putting it on.
Put it over your nose and mouth and secure it under your chin.
Make sure it fits snugly against the side of your face.
Slip the loops over your ears or tie the strings behind your head.
Do not touch it when you are wearing it.
Remove it by handling only the ear loops or ties and fold the outside corners together.
Be careful not to touch your eyes, nose or mouth, then wash your hands immediately after removing it.

Wash your mask regularly and make sure itâs completely dry before using it again. Have a few on hand so you can rotate them for washing and have enough clean ones to wear.
During hot weather, if you feel like you are overheating and are having trouble breathing because it is hot, take off your mask, drink water, rest and seek shade or a cool place. It is important that you stay at least 6 feet away from others whenever possible, especially when you are not wearing a mask.
During cold weather, change your mask when it becomes wet. Keep a spare mask to replace the wet one, and put the wet one in a plastic bag until you get home. If you need to wear a scarf, ski mask or balaclava, wear it over your mask. If you wear glasses, find a mask that fits closely over your nose or has a nose wire to help reduce fogging.
Wearing masks is one way we can help slow the spread of COVID-19 â in addition to staying at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with and other prevention steps.
Learn more:

Wearing face masks to keep COVID-19 from spreading
Face coverings for children
How to select, clean and wear your face mask

The State of Vermont is offering a limited number of free cloth face masks to the public. Find out if free cloth face masks are available in your area.

question: Do homemade cloth face masks or coverings work?
answer:
You are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces (for example, businesses, public buildings, parks), group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes), and other places where itâs not possible to stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
In private settings (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you wear a mask anytime you're around people you donât live with.
People with COVID-19 can spread the virus through respiratory droplets produced when they cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe. They can spread the virus even if they donât have any symptoms. Masks are a simple barrier to help prevent your respiratory droplets from reaching others. Studies show that masks reduce the spray of droplets when worn over your nose and mouth.
A mask also offers some protection to you,Â too. How well it protects you from breathing in the virus likely depends on the fabrics used and how your mask is made (for example, the type of fabric, the number of layers of fabric, how well the mask fits).
Find out which fabrics are best to use for cloth masks.
Learn more:

Wearing face masks to keep COVID-19 from spreading
Face coverings for children
How to select, clean and wear your face mask

The State of Vermont is offering a limited number of free cloth face masks to the public. Find out if free cloth face masks are available in your area.

question: How can we make holiday celebrations safer?
answer:
To slow the spread of COVID-19, Vermonters are not allowed to gather with anyone you donât live with. We know how hard it is to be apart from family and friends who we usually celebrate holidays with. Hereâs what you need to know:

Staying home and with people you live with is still the lowest risk.
If you do gather with people you donât live with, then you should quarantine after the gathering.
The Health Department strongly encourages getting tested as soon as possible after the gathering and then again on day 7.
The Health Department strongly advises against travel, even within Vermont. All travel to and from Vermont requires quarantine (unless itâs considered essential travel).

Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for 14 days. If you have not hadÂ symptoms of COVID-19, you have theÂ optionÂ to get a PCR test on day 7Â and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
Any time you are around others, remember to add these things: 6-Foot Spaces, Masks on Faces, Uncrowded Places. Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. The more layers there are, the safer everyone will be. Learn more about COVID-19 prevention steps.
Remember, the virus can spread easily among family and friends â because they are the ones we are often in close contact with â when they donât know they have it. Like other aspects of our lives, holidays will look different and we need to do everything we can to keep each other safe.
Find information for communities of faith.
Find more tips from the CDC:

Holiday celebrations
Hosting gatherings or cook-outs
Attending an event or gathering

question: Can I buy or sign a long-term lease (more than 30 days) for a new apartment or house?
answer:
Long-term rental leases are allowed. Moving and moving services are also allowed, as long as people stay at least 6 feet from people they donât live with. You are also required to wear a face mask or covering anytime you are around people you donât live with. More housing information is available at the Agency of Commerce and Community Development's (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Resource Recovery Center.
Out-of-state buyers and renters must follow the travel and quarantine requirements before coming to Vermont to visit a property. People moving to Vermont for work must also follow the quarantine requirements.
Real estate and related services (such as title searches, appraisals, and home inspections) are operating under certain health and safety requirements including staying at least 6 feet away from others and wearing face masks or coverings.
Find more details and up-to-date information on real estate from the ACCD.

question: Can I get together with friends and family?
answer:
As of November 14, 2020, you are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. This includes all inside and outside social and entertainment gatherings, and in public and private spaces. Learn more about what this means.
If you do gather with people you donât live with, you should quarantine. Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for 14 days. The Health Department strongly encourages you to get tested as soon as possible after the gathering and then again on day 7. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
If you are around other people, itâs safest to be outdoors. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19.
Follow these general prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.
Also, consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of the virus.
The risk for severe illness increases with age and is higher for older adults and people of any age with certain underlying medical conditions. They should consider taking additional steps to limit their risk, stay close to home, and family and friends should do everything they can to help keep them safe.
Learn more from the CDC:

Hosting gatherings or cook-outs
Attending an event or gathering

question: What is self-observation?
answer:
Self-observation is for Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19. Follow these prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a maskÂ anytime you are around people you donât live with.

Learn more about isolation, quarantine and self-observation.

question: I take care of someone who is in isolation because they tested positive for COVID-19, but I canât avoid close contact with them. Do I need to quarantine?
answer:
Yes. In situations where you cannot avoid close contact with someone with COVID-19, you should quarantine while the person you are caring for is sick. You should also quarantine for 14 days after they are able to end home isolation.
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from other people. Quarantine means you need to stay home and away from other people for 14 days since the day you were potentially exposed. You should separate yourself from others and check yourself for symptoms. Learn about the option to be tested to end quarantine after 7 days.
Find tips on what to do when a household member is sick with COVID-19.

question: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
answer:
If you are currently under quarantine and have had no symptoms of COVID-19 during the first seven days of quarantine, you have the option to be tested and end your quarantine early. The test must be a PCR test.
You can end your quarantine period before 14 days only if:

You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period;
You are tested on day 7 or later;
You remain in quarantine until the result comes back;
You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms; and
You continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days.

If you develop symptoms at any point during your quarantine, contact your health care provider and the Health Department right away.
There are a variety of testing options available to you: your health care provider, pharmacies and Health Department testing sites. Find out where to get tested.
If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
For travelers who are completing quarantine in their home state, your home state may offer testing for people without symptoms. Continue to quarantine until you travel to Vermont.
You must quarantine even if you had COVID-19, received a positive antibody test, or got a COVID-19 vaccine. Learn more about why.
Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by day 7. This is why there is the option for people to be tested on day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine.
Residents and staff of group living facilities (for example long-term care facilities or corrections facilities) and new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine.

question: I am having problems registering for my vaccine appointment. Who do I contact?
answer:
If you have questions or need help creating an account, scheduling an appointment, or signing up someone as a dependent, please call 855-722-7878.
Find out what to do if you are having problems registering for a test or have questions about your test results.

question: I want to travel to Vermont from a foreign country. Is that allowed?
answer:
All travel to and from Vermont now requires quarantine. The only exception is essential travel. The Health Department and the CDC strongly recommend not traveling right now.
If you are not a U.S. citizen, check the CDCâs travel page for advisories for travelers who are prohibited from entering the U.S. Also check the CDCâs guidance on testing and international travel.
Once you arrive in Vermont, you must quarantine for 14 days. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
Find out about travel from Canada.

question: Do I need to quarantine if I do a short trip (day trip)?
answer:
If you live near a state border and regularly travel to and from a neighboring state, you may make day trips to that state for work, health care, for students who commute daily to attend preK-12 school or college or a school-sponsored activity, and for other essential needs like groceries or visitation for parental shared custody, without quarantining.
The exemption to quarantineÂ only applies to the person under essential travel rules. It does not apply to anyone else who travels with you. For example, you travel for work and your child comes with you. Your child will need to quarantine for 14 days when you return to Vermont, but you wonât need to.
If you are traveling for leisure and go on a day trip, or travel by plane, train, bus or other means of public transportation, you must quarantine for 14 days in Vermont when you return.
Anyone who has not had symptoms of COVID-19, has the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end quarantine with a negative test result.
Find more travel and quarantine information.

question: What is a âprobable caseâ?
answer:
A case is considered âprobableâ if the person:

tested positive on an antigen test and has symptoms of COVID-19 or epidemiologic evidence, or
has symptoms of COVID-19 and is epidemiologically linked to a confirmed case of COVID-19.

As of December 2, probable cases are included in the number of COVID-19 cases in Vermont.
As of January 4, deaths among probable cases are included in the number of COVID-19 deaths in Vermont. A death among a probable case is a person who:

meets the probable case definition and has COVID-19 listed as a cause or contributing condition on their death certificate or
has COVID-19 listed as a cause or contributing condition on their death certificate.

The Health Department follows the nationally recognized definition of COVID-19 cases, developed by the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists (CSTE) in April 2020. Since then, the Health Department has tracked probable cases and taken the same public health actions as if they were a confirmed case (confirmed means the person tested positive on a PCR test).
This means that contact tracers conduct interviews with people who are considered probable cases, provide isolation guidance, and their close contacts are notified to quarantine. People who are considered probable cases are also encouraged to get a follow-up PCR test. If they test positive on a follow-up PCR test, they are only included once in the total case count.
The Health Department began including probable cases and deaths in counts to more accurately represent COVID-19 activity and because antigen testing in Vermont is increasing. Right now, this change does not impact hospitalization or testing data.

question: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
answer:
People with COVID-19 have had a wide range of symptoms reported â ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. Symptoms may start 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus. People with these symptoms may have COVID-19:

Fever (100.4Â°F or greater)
Cough
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Chills
Fatigue
Muscle or body aches
Headache
New loss of taste or smell
Sore throat
Congestion or runny nose
Nausea or vomiting
Diarrhea

This list does not include all possible symptoms. The CDC will continue to update the list of symptoms as more is learned. You can check your symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.
Not everyone with COVID-19 has a fever. Even mild symptoms (like a headache or dry cough) could be signs of COVID-19.
Not everyone infected with the COVID-19 virus has symptoms. People with COVID-19 who don't have any symptoms can spread the virus to other people. Learn how to protect yourself and others.
All Vermonters, even with mild symptoms, are encouraged to contact their health care provider to get tested. Your provider will test you at their office or refer you for testing nearby. Stay home while waiting for your result.
If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
Learn more about what to do if you have COVID-19.

question: I am having problems registering for a test or receiving my results. Who do I contact?
answer:
If you have questions or need help creating an account, registering for a test, or if you have questions about receiving your test results, please call 802-863-7240 option 9.
Find out what to do if you are having problems registering for your vaccine appointment.

question: Does being vaccinated affect my COVID-19 test results?
answer:
No. The COVID-19 vaccines that are available and the other vaccines currently in clinical trials in the United States will not cause you to test positive on viral tests. PCR and antigen tests are viral tests, and will tell you if you are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.
If your body develops an immune response, which is what happens when you get vaccinated, there is a possibility you may test positive on some antibody tests. Antibody, or serologic, tests measure the bodyâs immune response to the virus and show that you may have some level of protection against the virus. Experts are currently looking at how getting the COVID-19 vaccine may affect antibody testing results.

question: What do I need to know about COVID-19 testing? Where can I get tested?
answer:
You can get tested at a Health Department testing site if you live or work in Vermont and do not have symptoms. This includes children 12 months or older. Anyone under 18 should be accompanied by a parent or guardian or bring a signed parental consent form.
There are a variety of testing options available to you: your health care provider, pharmacies and Health Department testing sites. Find out where to get tested and how to schedule an appointment.
If you have symptoms of COVID-19, do not go to a testing site. Talk to your health care provider. If you don't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.
The Health Department recommends testing as soon as possible when:

you have symptoms of COVID-19 (call your health care provider first).
you are referred by your health care provider.
a person in your workplace or household, or a person you attended an event with, tests positive for COVID-19.
you plan on going to a social gathering with people you don't live with (other than recreating with one masked person outside). You should get tested before the gathering, right after, and again on day 7.

If you often gather socially with people you don't live with, you should get tested weekly.
College students returning to Vermont from out of state should quarantine and be tested on or after day 7 of quarantine after returning home.
Travelers to Vermont and Vermonters returning from out of state must follow quarantine requirements. You have the option to get a PCR test on or after day 7 of quarantine and end your quarantine early with a negative test result.
There is no cost to individuals for a PCR test for COVID-19, even if you donât have health insurance.
You may come to a Health Department testing site to get tested more than once if you have reason to be concerned about infection.
Health Department testing sites use nasal swabs. This is a self-administered test, which means that you use a short, dry swab to collect a sample from the front of your nose.
If you need a ride to the testing site, schedule your appointment first, and then call 833-387-7200 at least two days before the appointment.
Find out:

Where to get tested and how to schedule an appointment
What to expect at a Health Department testing site â including answers to more questions about testing
What to do while youâre waiting for test results and how to get your test results
When you will get your test results
What the different types of tests are
How many Vermonters have been tested â this information is updated daily.

question: How can children stay safe and prevent the spread of COVID-19?
answer:
As of November 14, 2020, you are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. This includes all inside and outside social and entertainment gatherings, and in public and private spaces. Learn more about what this means.
If you do gather with people you donât live with, you should quarantine. Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for 14 days. The Health Department strongly encourages you to get tested as soon as possible after the gathering and then again on day 7. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
If you are around other people, itâs safest to be outdoors. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19.
Gathering in groups or âpodsâ related to education or child care that are already formed can continue. Gathering in pods related to social activity, informal playgroups, playdates, or sleepovers are not allowed at this time. New pods of any kind are discouraged.
Follow these general prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask (children over 2 who are able) anytime you are around people you donât live with.

There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.
Children can also continue to take advantage of technology to play games or keep in touch with friends and family. These changes will continue to be difficult, but we are all doing our part to slow down this pandemic.
Learn more:

Resources for families with children
Coping with family stress during COVID-19
Face coverings for children
Frequently asked questions about school

question: What do I do if I test positive for COVID-19?
answer:
Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.
If you or a family member are sick, follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and your community:
Isolate at home

Stay home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting your health care provider. Anyone who does not have a health care provider can call 2-1-1 to be connected to care or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.
Separate yourself from other people and pets**.**
Monitor your symptoms.
Wear a face mask or covering when you're around people and pets.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with your sleeve or a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Wash your hands often. Use an alcohol-based sanitizer if soap and water aren't available.
Avoid sharing personal household items**.**
Clean all high-touch surfaces in your home daily.
Get support from others. Stay in touch with family and friends by phone, email or online platform.

Someone from the Health Department will contact you to ask for your help with contact tracing. Contact tracing is used to provide education, support and guidance to people who are diagnosed with an infectious disease. Itâs also used to identify people who have been in close contact with them, so they can take steps to stop the disease from spreading to others.
Learn more:

Caring for yourself at home from the CDC
10 ways to manage respiratory symptoms at home from the CDC
Information on breastfeeding if you have COVID-19 from the CDC
What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation
What to do if you test positive for COVID-19

question: I am turning 75 soon. Can I make an appointment now?
answer: You will have to wait until you turn 75 until you can schedule an appointment. This is because the system asks for your date of birth and only allows people who are currently 75 and older to schedule one. There will be enough vaccine appointment slots available for you to register.

question: What kind of assistance will be available at my vaccine appointment? Can someone come with me?
answer:
All vaccine clinics will be handicap accessible. Wheelchairs are available at all Health Department vaccination sites and at hospitals.
Language interpreters (including ASL) can be arranged at Health Department vaccination sites. Usually, the interpreter will work with you remotely by phone or video conference through a computer available at the site. To request an interpreter, ask one of the public health workers at the site. Some sites, including Burlington and Winooski, will have in-person interpreters based on demand for these services in the area.
If you need physical assistance getting to your vaccine appointment, you can have one other person come with you. You will both have your temperatures taken and will be asked questions to determine if you have any current COVID-19 symptoms. If either of you do, then the person who has symptoms wonât be allowed to go any further.
You will both need to wear masks during your appointment. If you do not have one, there will be masks available at the clinic. If you have trouble breathing, are unable to remove your mask by yourself, or have a medical reason for not wearing one, you will not be required to wear a mask.
Find out what to do if you need a ride to your appointment.

question: I donât have an email address. How do I schedule an appointment?
answer:
If you donât have an email address, you can call 855-722-7878 to schedule your appointment over the phone. However, you will not get an appointment reminder since those are being sent by email. The call center is open Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.
Another option would be to ask a family member to create an online account with their email address. Your family member will be able to add you as a âdependentâ to schedule and assist with managing your appointments. Learn more about making an appointment for someone else.

question: What can I expect at my vaccine appointment?
answer:
You will need to wear a mask during your appointment. If you do not have one, there will be one available for you at the clinic. If you have trouble breathing, are unable to remove it yourself, or have a medical reason for not wearing one, you will not be required to wear a mask.
Remember to dress warmly for the weather.Â Arrive on time so you donât have to wait long, or keep others waiting.Â Please do not arrive earlier than 15 minutes before your appointment. If you need someone to come with you for assistance, please only bring one person so we can limit the number of people inside the clinics and make sure people are properly distanced.
Once you arrive at the vaccine clinic, here is what will happen:

Before you enter the clinic, someone will take your temperature and ask questions to determine if you have any current symptoms of COVID-19. If you do, then you will be asked to reschedule your appointment.
You will go inside and check in. You will be asked to fill out paperwork, which will include a health screening questionnaire.
You will be asked to go to a vaccination station where you will get the vaccine in your arm.
You will be given a handout with information about the vaccine you got and any possible side effects to watch out for, as well as how to report any reactions or side effects you may have.
You will be asked to stay for 15 to 30 minutes so you can be watched for any side effects.
Someone will help you schedule an appointment to get your second dose of vaccine at a later date.

question: What do I do if my COVID-19 test is inconclusive?
answer: An âinconclusiveâ or âindeterminateâ result means the test was neither positive nor negative. If you receive a test result that is âinconclusiveâ or âindeterminate,â the Health Department encourages you to get retested. Find out where to get tested.

question: I donât have my own transportation. Can I get a ride to my vaccine appointment?
answer:
Yes. Free public transportation to vaccine clinics is available to Vermont residents who do not have their own transportation. Rides are coordinated by the Vermont Public Transportation Association. Volunteer drivers will use cars, vans or buses. All rides are ADA compliant and will accommodate people living with disabilities.
Please make a request at least 48 hours before your vaccine appointment. These rides are subject to the availability of transportation resources, so advance notice is necessary to make sure you will have a ride.
Rides are only available if you are not sick with COVID-19 (with symptoms or without symptoms) or are not a close contact of someone who has COVID-19. If you recently traveled, you need to follow the current travel quarantine requirements before you can request a ride. If you fall into one of these categories, you will need to answer some questions to find out when you can use public transportation.
Find contact information for your local public transportation provider.

question: What should pregnant or breastfeeding people do?
answer:
Based on what we know at this time,Â pregnant peopleÂ are at an increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19 and death,Â compared to non-pregnant people. Additionally, pregnant people with COVID-19 might be at increased risk of other adverse outcomes, such as preterm birth (delivering the baby earlier than 37 weeks). Therefore,Â it is especially important for pregnant people, and those who live with them, to protect themselves from getting COVID-19.
We donât know for sure if people with COVID-19 can spread the virus to babies through their breast milk, but the current evidence suggests that this isnât likely.
Learn more from the CDC about COVID-19 and pregnancy and breastfeeding.
Find more resources for families with children.

question: Can I get the virus from food?
answer:
According to CDC, although the virus can survive for a short period on some surfaces, it is unlikely to be spread from domestic or international mail, products or packaging.
The COVID-19 virus is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person. It is possible that a person could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or eyes, but this is not thought to be a common way that COVID-19 spreads. This can be prevented by washing your hands before you touch your face, mouth or eyes.
The CDC recommends washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or using a hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol after collecting mail from a post office or home mailbox.

question: What happens if a vaccine clinic is canceled due to weather?
answer:
Check your local news station or the Health Departmentâs website and social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram) for any changes to Health Department vaccine clinic schedules due to weather.
If the Health Department vaccine clinic is not canceled but youâd like to reschedule your appointment because of the weather, call 855-722-7878.
If you registered to get your vaccine at Kinney Drugs, contact the store where your appointment is to find out if the clinic will be open or how to reschedule.
No matter what, you should always watch the weather and stay home if you don't feel safe traveling. There are enough vaccine appointments for everyone who is eligible â we will get you rescheduled if needed.

question: Do I need to quarantine if I live with someone or had close contact with someone who is under quarantine?
answer:
No. You do not need to quarantine if you had close contact with someone who is under quarantine. That means you can go to school, work, or the grocery store.
If you are living with someone who is under quarantine, stay at least 6 feet from them. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.

question: How many cases of COVID-19 are in the U.S.?
answer: You can find a school-by-school listing of COVID-19 cases in Vermont K-12 schools. The list will be updated on Tuesdays and Fridays with data through the previous Sunday and Wednesday, respectively.

question: How many people are being monitored in Vermont?
answer:
The number of travelers monitored and the number of contacts monitored are updated daily on theÂ Vermont Dashboard. You can find information on how the data for travelers monitored and contacts monitored are reportedÂ in the notes section of the dashboard. There are also more frequently asked questions about the data above the dashboard.
Weekly Data Summaries include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

question: What is known about the new variants of the COVID-19 virus?
answer:
Viruses constantly change through mutation, and new variants of a virus are expected to occur over time. Sometimes new variants emerge and disappear. Other times, they emerge and persist. Multiple variants of the virus that causes COVID-19 have been documented in the United States and globally during this pandemic.
According to the CDC, multiple COVID-19 variants are circulating globally, namely in the United Kingdom (UK), South Africa and Brazil.
The UK variant, called B.1.1.7, has been detected in numerous countries around the world. This variant was first detected in the U.S. at the end of December 2020. In January 2021, experts in the UK reported that this variant may be associated with an increased risk of death compared to other variant viruses, but more studies are needed to confirm this finding.
These variants seem to spread more easily and quickly than other variants, which may lead to more cases of COVID-19. An increase in the number of cases will put more strain on health care resources, lead to more hospitalizations, and potentially more deaths. You can find a map showing the number of confirmed cases caused by variants in the U.S.
Information about these variants is rapidly emerging. Scientists are working to learn more about how easily they spread, whether they could cause more severe illness, and whether currently authorized vaccines will protect people against them.
Learn more about what we know, what we donât know, and what the CDC is doing about new COVID-19 variants.

question: What is the Health Department doing?
answer:
The Health Department has put into place appropriate measures to protect businesses and Health Department staff. Emergencies and foodborne outbreak investigations are still being responded to during the COVID-19 pandemic.
If you have a complaint about a restaurant, you can submit an illness or sanitation complaint online, email FoodLodging@vermont.gov, or call 802-863-7221.

question: I’ve heard that home remedies can cure or prevent the virus.
answer:
There’s no evidence from the outbreak that eating garlic, sipping water every 15 minutes or taking vitamin C will protect people from the new coronavirus. Same goes for using essential oils, colloidal silver and steroids.
Some posts have suggested that putting sesame oil on your body or spraying yourself with alcohol or chlorine will kill the virus. That’s also false.

question: Can you safely reuse a non-cloth mask that you can’t wash, like a disposable mask?
answer:
Yes you can, said Dr. Joseph Vinetz, an infectious diseases professor at Yale School of Medicine. 
To disinfect masks that you can’t wash, Vinetz recommends leaving them in a clean, safe place in your home for a few days. After that, it should no longer be infectious, as this coronavirus is known to survive on hard surfaces for only up to three days. 
You can reuse cloth masks, too. Just launder them between each use on a high-heat setting. 
Learn more about which masks you shouldn’t buy and how you can make your own (without having to sew) here.

question: What’s so different about coronavirus that we have to shut down businesses? Why practice social distancing now, when we didn’t during the SARS and swine flu epidemics?
answer:
Unlike SARS and swine flu, the novel coronavirus is both highly contagious and especially deadly, CNN Chief Medical Correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta said. 
“SARS was also a coronavirus, and it was a new virus at the time,” Gupta said. “In the end, we know that SARS ended up infecting 8,000 people around the world and causing around 800 deaths. So very high fatality rate, but it didn’t turn out to be very contagious.”
The swine flu, or H1N1, “was very contagious and infected some 60 million people in the United States alone within a year,” Gupta said. “But it was far less lethal than the flu even — like 1/3 as lethal as the flu.” 
What makes the novel coronavirus different is that “this is both very contagious … and it appears to be far more lethal than the flu as well,” Gupta said. “So both those things, in combination I think, are why we’re taking this so seriously.”

question: This isolation is taking a toll on my mental health. And I’m starting to feel depressed and anxious about the pandemic. How can I get help?
answer:
The Crisis Text Line is available texting to 741741. Trained volunteers and crisis counselors are staffed 24/7, and the service is free. 
The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration Disaster Distress Helpline provides 24/7, 365-day-a-year crisis counseling and support to people experiencing emotional distress related to disasters. Call 1-800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746 to connect with a trained crisis counselor.
For health care professionals and essential workers, For the Frontlines offers free 24/7 crisis counseling and support for workers dealing with stress, anxiety, fear or isolation related to coronavirus. 
For more resources, check out CNN’s guide to giving and getting help during the pandemic.

question: Will ingesting or injecting disinfectants, like the ones that kill viruses on surfaces, protect me against coronavirus or kill coronavirus if I already have it?
answer:
“That’s a bad idea,” said Dr. Colleen Kraft, an infectious diseases professor at Emory University School of Medicine. “It could definitely kill you.” 
President Donald Trump wondered aloud during a press conference whether there’s “a way we can do something like that, by injection inside or almost a cleaning.”
But the Reckitt Benckiser Group, which produces Lysol cleaning products, said “under no circumstance” should disinfectants be put into the human body.

question: Is it true young people with coronavirus are also having blood clots and strokes?
answer:
Yes, some young adults have suffered strokes after getting coronavirus. 
“The virus seems to be causing increased clotting in the large arteries, leading to severe stroke,” said Dr. Thomas Oxley, a neurosurgeon at Mount Sinai Health System in New York.
“Our report shows a seven-fold increase in incidence of sudden stroke in young patients during the past two weeks,” he said. “Most of these patients have no past medical history and were at home with either mild symptoms (or in two cases, no symptoms) of Covid.”
At least one patient has died, and others are in rehabilitation facilities, intensive care or in the stroke unit, Oxley said. Only one patient went home, but will require intense care.

question: What can we learn from how other countries handled coronavirus?
answer:
Singapore was initially praised for its clampdown on the virus. Even people who had no symptoms but tested positive had to be hospitalized until they tested negative. 
But Singapore was also relaxed, allowing businesses, churches, restaurants and schools to stay open during its first wave of the virus. And some communities were overlooked by government testing.
The number of cases in Singapore shot up, and the country suffered a strong second wave of coronavirus. 
By contrast, Germany, South Korea, Iceland and Taiwan have been able to suppress the virus. They also have among the lowest death rates from Covid-19 in the world. 
Taiwan was proactive, launching its Central Epidemic Command Center before the island even confirmed its first infection. 
Iceland required all its citizens returning to the country to undergo 14 days of quarantine – regardless of which country they traveled from.
Germany and South Korea quickly launched widespread testing and have some of the highest per-capita testing rates in the world. Their ability to identify and isolate those infected has helped prevent deadlier outcomes.

question: Can coronavirus stick to clothes? Do I need to wash my clothes right after encountering other people, like at the grocery store or while jogging?
answer:
“I don’t think you need to,” CNN Chief Medical Correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta said. 
Coronavirus can stay alive for up to three days on stainless steel and plastic. But clothing “is probably more like cardboard — it’s more absorbent, so the virus is unlikely to stay and last that long,” Gupta said. 
While covonravirus can stay alive on cardboard for up to 24 hours, viruses generally don’t stick well on surfaces that are in motion. 
“If you look at how viruses move through air, they kind of want to move around objects,” Gupta said. “They don’t want to necessarily land on objects. So if you’re moving as human body through the air … (it’s) unlikely to stick to your clothes.”

question: Can coronavirus spread through water, like in a swimming pool or hot tub?
answer:
“There is no evidence that COVID-19 can be spread to humans through the use of pools and hot tubs,” the CDC says. 
“Proper operation, maintenance, and disinfection (e.g., with chlorine and bromine) of pools and hot tubs should remove or inactivate the virus that causes COVID-19.”
But health officials still advise staying at least 6 feet away from others because COVID-19 is a respiratory disease. In other words, you probably won’t get coronavirus from the water, but you could get coronavirus from someone close to you in the water. 
As for drinking water, doctors say you don’t need to worry about coronavirus in the tap water because most municipal drinking water systems should remove or inactivate the virus.

question: Will an antibody test show whether I’m immune and can go back to work?
answer:
Not necessarily. Antibodies are a body’s response to bacteria or viruses. But this novel coronavirus is so new, it’s still not clear whether having antibodies to it means you have long-term protection from getting reinfected. 
“The thing we don’t know yet is what is the relationship between the level of antibody and the degree of your protection,” Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, told Snapchat’s “Good Luck America” show. 
“So you may be positive for an antibody, but not enough to protect you.” 
There’s also a risk that some antibody tests might confuse the novel coronavirus with other coronaviruses, like the ones that cause the common cold.

question: Can I use vodka as hand sanitizer?
answer:
Please don’t. The CDC advises using hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.
Vodka typically contains between 35% and 46% percent alcohol.
If the stores are out of hand sanitizer and you want to make your own, the Nebraska Medical Center offers this recipe:
What you’ll need:

2/3 cup 91% isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol)
1/3 cup aloe vera gel
Mixing bowl
Spoon or something for whisking
Small container, such as a 3-oz. travel bottle
Optional: essential oil to give your hand sanitizer a fragrance

Directions:In a mixing bowl, stir isopropyl alcohol and aloe vera gel together until well blended.Add 8-10 drops of scented essential oil (optional, but nice). Stir.Pour the homemade hand sanitizer into an empty container and seal. Write “hand sanitizer” on a piece of masking tape and attach to the bottle.

question: Are smokers or vapers at higher risk? What if I only smoke weed?
answer:
